SECTION 2 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. PROFILE

2.1 ACTIVITIES

Business Monitor International Inc. provides Country Risk and industry research analysis in the United States. The company was incorporated in 2009 and is based in New York, New York. Business Monitor International Inc. operates as a subsidiary of Business Monitor International Ltd.

2.2 SUMMARY

PermID: 4296431365

Website: http://www.businessmonitor.com

Industry: Software and Technology Servic

SECTION 3 PRESS RELEASES: 2020

June 04: Business Monitor International Inc.: Bahamas Poor Fiscal Outlook To Constrain Healthcare Spending

We at Fitch Solutions see downside risks to Bahamas growth as the coronavirus pandemic may cause extended damage to the tourism industry. The government's healthcare budget will come under pressure in the near term, as the Bahamas recovers from Hurricane Dorian and the Covid-19 impact. The Bahamas could increasingly attract investment from active pharmaceutical ingr.

Source: Company Website

May 13: Business Monitor International Inc.: Myanmar Emergency Tenders To Support Gas-Fired Power Growth

We have revised our Myanmar thermal capacity forecasts to account for the progress of several gas-fired projects under emergency tenders. While these projects have faced delays and missed their operational deadlines as we expected, progress will mean that they are likely to still come online within two years, by a conservative estimate.

Source: Company Website

April 03: Business Monitor International Inc.: Collaborations Aim To Eliminate Medical Device Shortages Caused By Covid-19

Due to the increasing prevalence of Covid-19 (coronavirus), the demand for ventilators, personal protective equipment and testing devices is likely to remain unmet in the short term. In order to meet the sudden demand for respiratory devices, large medical device companies such as GE healthcare are collaborating with both medical and non-medical manufacturers. The d.

Source: Company Website

March 20: Business Monitor International Inc.: Big Tech After Covid-19: Cash And Regulation

We believe the Big Tech companies are in a strong position to expand post-coronavirus. There could be greater divergence between the US and the EU when it comes to tech regulation.

Source: Company Website

March 19: Business Monitor International Inc.: Gym And Fitness Subscription A Trend To Watch In China, Despite Covid-19 Outbreak

A large youth population, expanding wealth and increasing health awareness are the demand drivers behind the gym and fitness-as-a-subscription services (yoga, spin, boxing) expansion in China. While this sector has struggled during the Covid-19 (coronavirus) outbreak, we believe that this will be a short term dampening to this trend, as the underlying fundamentals remain in place. We believe that international and domestic fitness service providers that continue to innovate, and continue to offer unique exercise experiences will be best placed to grow their offering and engage wit.

Source: Company Website

March 04: Business Monitor International Inc.: Sub-Saharan Africa 4G Developments: Licences, Launches And Investment

Operators remain focused on deploying advanced mobile data services in Sub-Saharan Africa, but driving uptake and monetisation remain long-term plays. Facing highly competitive operating environments, players will focus on boosting their spectrum assets and ensuring superior network quality and reach as competitive differentiators.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 4 OTHER NEWS: 2020

July 31: Business Monitor International Inc.: Ukraine Medical Device Market Outlook Positive

The 2020 medical devices market is being driven by demand for supplies to combat Covid-19, but growth will return to normal once the pandemic subsides. Government relief packages throughout the pandemic will not provide long-term support to the market.

Source: Company Website

July 31: Business Monitor International Inc.: Alternative Protein: Beyond Meat Playing Catch-Up As It Enters Brazilian Market

This report from Fitch Solutions Country Risk & Industry Research is a product of Fitch Solutions Group Ltd, UK Company registration number 08789939 ('FSG'). FSG is an affiliate of Fitch Ratings Inc.

July 31: Business Monitor International Inc.: Bulgaria Consumer Outlook: 2020 Covid-19 Impact Assessment And 2021 Recovery Scenario

Relaxation of movement restrictions, travel recommencing, non-essential retail and hospitality re-opening and the launch of government stimulus packages, are all being taken into account in our forecasts for the Bulgaria consumer spending outlook in the short-to-medium term (2020-2024). The spread of Covid-19 globally will have a negative impact on Bulgaria's consumer spending in 2020, with real household spending forecast to contract by -6.0% y-o-y. In 2021 we project a recovery of 8.5% y-o-y growth.

Source: Company Website

July 30: Business Monitor International Inc.: Covid-19 Will Delay Philippines' Goal Of Achieving Universal Healthcare

This report from Fitch Solutions Country Risk & Industry Research is a product of Fitch Solutions Group Ltd, UK Company registration number 08789939 ('FSG').

Source: Company Website

July 27: Business Monitor International Inc.: Coping With Covid-19: Financial Aid Packages Will Increase Healthcare Spending In APAC

This report from Fitch Solutions Country Risk & Industry Research is a product of Fitch Solutions Group Ltd, UK Company registration number 08789939 ('FSG').

Source: Company Website

July 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Netherlands 5G Spectrum Auction: High Prices For Small Market

The Netherlands has completed its initial 5G spectrum auction, raising EUR1.23bn. Bids were relatively high, reflecting the three incumbents' robust IoT pedigrees. The risk is that they may have overpaid in an effort to secure access to a small industrial IoT market.

T-Mobile appears to have come off worst in the auction, securing 70MHz.

Source: Company Website

July 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Covid-19 Funding Will Create Commercial Opportunities For Medical Devices In The Philippines

Despite an expected economic recession in the Philippines in 2020, which will pose headwinds to the medical device market, commercial opportunities are still on the rise. Funding from the Philippines Charity Sweepstakes Office (PCSO), as well as the Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corporation (PAGCOR), will provide opportunities for medical device manufacturers and suppliers.

Source: Company Website

July 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Off-Trade Coffee Spending Boosted By Covid-19 Pandemic

At Fitch Solutions, we believe that consumer spending on coffee (through retail channels) will receive a significant boost in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. We project consumer spending on coffee globally to increase by 5.8% y-o-y (in US dollar terms) in 2020, which is significantly up from the estimated growth of 0.1% y-o-y in 2019 and the average annual growth rate of 1.0% over 2.

Source: Company Website

July 22: Business Monitor International Inc.: Pent-Up Investor Demand Paving Way For Smaller Brazilian Floats

Despite being home to one of the world's largest stock exchanges, Brazil has struggled to record a strong flow of IPO activity over recent years. We believe that deal levels on the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange (or commonly known as the Bovespa bourse) will also remain low in the near term, with the country expected to see a forecast sharp contraction in economic growth in 2020. At Fitch Solutions, we forecast the Brazilian econ.

Source: Company Website

July 22: Business Monitor International Inc.: Japanese Subsidies Will Further Benefit South East Asia's Ability To Attract Autos Investment

Japan's push to reduce its industries' reliance on Chinese manufacturing by subsidising the relocation of manufacturing facilities out of China and not only back to Japan, but also into the wider South East Asia region, will greatly benefit countries in South East Asia. One of the key themes that emerged from this first round of incentives is that the manufacturing of steel c.

Source: Company Website

July 21: Business Monitor International Inc.: What Our Clients Want To Know: Commodities After Covid-19

On June 30, Fitch Solutions held a webinar, 'Commodities After-Covid-19: Trends And Opportunities', in which we discussed the short-term impact of the pandemic on commodities prices and long-term implications for the agribusiness and mining & metals sectors. In this article, we answer some of the most asked questions received during the webinar's Q&A session.

Source: Company Website

July 21: Business Monitor International Inc.: USMCA Gives Mexico Advantage As Global Supply Chains Shift

The effectuation of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) will compound the existing factors supporting Mexico as a beneficiary of automotive supply chain diversification. Mexico's comparatively attractive operating environment and proximity to the US and Canada inform our assessment that it will benefit from a reallocation of automotive production resources after the Covid-.

Source: Company Website

July 16: Business Monitor International Inc.: Argentina's Vehicle Production Faces Unprecedented Threat From Covid-19

The Covid-19 pandemic poses an unprecedented threat to Argentina's vehicle output as it causes disruption to production while also dampening the demand for new vehicles. The weak economic outlook will provide little support for Argentina's vehicle production industry as it will severely dampen the demand for new vehicles. In 2020, we expect Argentina's vehicle sales.

Source: Company Website

July 16: Business Monitor International Inc.: Spain To Impose Targeted Regional Lockdown As New Confirmed Covid-19 Cases Doubled

Targeted regional lockdown in Spain as new infection doubled post nationwide lockdown. ROVI's facility in Madrid to manufacture Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine candidate. 95% of Spain's population remains susceptible to Covid-19 virus.

Source: Company Website

July 15: Business Monitor International Inc.: Asia Autos Production: Japan Regains Second Place, But Is Not Without Challenges

In the most recent update of our Autos Production RRI, the Asia region's overall score has remained stable at 56.2 out of a possible 100. As such, the region maintains its position as the most attractive region for vehicle production globally, followed by Europe (53.8) and the Americas (43.4). The Asia region benefits from major automotive countries, such as China, Japan and India, all having large volume vehicle production, healthy completion, a good pool of skilled labour and strong automotive policies. However, production growth scores in these markets have fallen due to the spread of Covid-19. We highlight that Japan is not shielded from suppressed output amid the pandemic, which means that its overall score is being held back by its performance under our 'Vehicle production growth' indicator on our Risk/Reward Index.

Strength Of China's Autos Industry Keeps It On Top Asia - Autos Production Risk/Reward Index Heat Map

Note: Scores out of 100; higher score = more attractive market. Source: Fitch Solutions Autos Production Risk/Reward Index Main Regional Features And Latest Updates

In the most recent update of our Autos Production Risk/Reward Index (RRI), the Asia region's overall score has remained stable at 56.2 out of a possible 100.

SECTION 5 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

Simon Longfield, CFO

Terence Alexander, Chief Operating Officer

Jon Ewing, Chief Technology Officer & Chief Marketing Officer

Diane Milliard, Global Head of HR and Recruitment

Gregory Roth, Global Head-Communications

Lyndsey Anderson, Global Head-Research

July 21: Business Monitor International Inc.: What Our Clients Want To Know: Commodities After Covid-19

On June 30, Fitch Solutions held a webinar, 'Commodities After-Covid-19: Trends And Opportunities', in which we discussed the short-term impact of the pandemic on commodities prices and long-term implications for the agribusiness and mining & metals sectors. In this article, we answer some of the most asked questions received during the webinar's Q&A session.

Source: Company Website

July 21: Business Monitor International Inc.: USMCA Gives Mexico Advantage As Global Supply Chains Shift

The effectuation of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) will compound the existing factors supporting Mexico as a beneficiary of automotive supply chain diversification. Mexico's comparatively attractive operating environment and proximity to the US and Canada inform our assessment that it will benefit from a reallocation of automotive production resources after the Covid-.

Source: Company Website

July 16: Business Monitor International Inc.: Argentina's Vehicle Production Faces Unprecedented Threat From Covid-19

The Covid-19 pandemic poses an unprecedented threat to Argentina's vehicle output as it causes disruption to production while also dampening the demand for new vehicles. The weak economic outlook will provide little support for Argentina's vehicle production industry as it will severely dampen the demand for new vehicles. In 2020, we expect Argentina's vehicle sales.

Source: Company Website

July 16: Business Monitor International Inc.: Spain To Impose Targeted Regional Lockdown As New Confirmed Covid-19 Cases Doubled

Targeted regional lockdown in Spain as new infection doubled post nationwide lockdown. ROVI's facility in Madrid to manufacture Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine candidate. 95% of Spain's population remains susceptible to Covid-19 virus.

Source: Company Website

July 15: Business Monitor International Inc.: Asia Autos Production: Japan Regains Second Place, But Is Not Without Challenges

In the most recent update of our Autos Production RRI, the Asia region's overall score has remained stable at 56.2 out of a possible 100. As such, the region maintains its position as the most attractive region for vehicle production globally, followed by Europe (53.8) and the Americas (43.4). The Asia region benefits from major automotive countries, such as China, Japan and India, all having large volume vehicle production, healthy completion, a good pool of skilled labour and strong automotive policies. However, production growth scores in these markets have fallen due to the spread of Covid-19. We highlight that Japan is not shielded from suppressed output amid the pandemic, which means that its overall score is being held back by its performance under our 'Vehicle production growth' indicator on our Risk/Reward Index.

Strength Of China's Autos Industry Keeps It On Top Asia - Autos Production Risk/Reward Index Heat Map

Note: Scores out of 100; higher score = more attractive market. Source: Fitch Solutions Autos Production Risk/Reward Index Main Regional Features And Latest Updates

In the most recent update of our Autos Production Risk/Reward Index (RRI), the Asia region's overall score has remained stable at 56.2 out of a possible 100.

SECTION 5 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

Simon Longfield, CFO

Terence Alexander, Chief Operating Officer

Jon Ewing, Chief Technology Officer & Chief Marketing Officer

Diane Milliard, Global Head of HR and Recruitment

Gregory Roth, Global Head-Communications

Lyndsey Anderson, Global Head-Research

urn:contentItem:60GN-J8C1-JB4F-Y32T-00000-00July 31, 2020: Business Monitor International Inc.: Bulgaria Consumer Outlook: 2020 Covid-19 Impact Assessment And 2021 Recovery Scenario2020-08-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 31, 2020: Business Monitor International Inc.: Bulgaria Consumer Outlook: 2020 Covid-19 Impact Assessment And 2021 Recovery Scenario

Relaxation of movement restrictions, travel recommencing, non-essential retail and hospitality re-opening and the launch of government stimulus packages, are all being taken into account in our forecasts for the Bulgaria consumer spending outlook in the short-to-medium term (2020-2024). The spread of Covid-19 globally will have a negative impact on Bulgaria's consumer spending in 2020, with real household spending forecast to contract by -6.0% y-o-y. In 2021 we project a recovery of 8.5% y-o-y growth.

June 04: Business Monitor International Inc.: Bahamas Poor Fiscal Outlook To Constrain Healthcare Spending

We at Fitch Solutions see downside risks to Bahamas growth as the coronavirus pandemic may cause extended damage to the tourism industry. The government's healthcare budget will come under pressure in the near term, as the Bahamas recovers from Hurricane Dorian and the Covid-19 impact. The Bahamas could increasingly attract investment from active pharmaceutical ingr.

Source: Company Website

May 13: Business Monitor International Inc.: Myanmar Emergency Tenders To Support Gas-Fired Power Growth

We have revised our Myanmar thermal capacity forecasts to account for the progress of several gas-fired projects under emergency tenders. While these projects have faced delays and missed their operational deadlines as we expected, progress will mean that they are likely to still come online within two years, by a conservative estimate.

Source: Company Website

April 03: Business Monitor International Inc.: Collaborations Aim To Eliminate Medical Device Shortages Caused By Covid-19

Due to the increasing prevalence of Covid-19 (coronavirus), the demand for ventilators, personal protective equipment and testing devices is likely to remain unmet in the short term. In order to meet the sudden demand for respiratory devices, large medical device companies such as GE healthcare are collaborating with both medical and non-medical manufacturers. The d.

Source: Company Website

March 20: Business Monitor International Inc.: Big Tech After Covid-19: Cash And Regulation

We believe the Big Tech companies are in a strong position to expand post-coronavirus. There could be greater divergence between the US and the EU when it comes to tech regulation.

Source: Company Website

March 19: Business Monitor International Inc.: Gym And Fitness Subscription A Trend To Watch In China, Despite Covid-19 Outbreak

A large youth population, expanding wealth and increasing health awareness are the demand drivers behind the gym and fitness-as-a-subscription services (yoga, spin, boxing) expansion in China. While this sector has struggled during the Covid-19 (coronavirus) outbreak, we believe that this will be a short term dampening to this trend, as the underlying fundamentals remain in place. We believe that international and domestic fitness service providers that continue to innovate, and continue to offer unique exercise experiences will be best placed to grow their offering and engage wit.

Source: Company Website

March 04: Business Monitor International Inc.: Sub-Saharan Africa 4G Developments: Licences, Launches And Investment

Operators remain focused on deploying advanced mobile data services in Sub-Saharan Africa, but driving uptake and monetisation remain long-term plays. Facing highly competitive operating environments, players will focus on boosting their spectrum assets and ensuring superior network quality and reach as competitive differentiators.

Source: Company Website

July 31: Business Monitor International Inc.: Ukraine Medical Device Market Outlook Positive

The 2020 medical devices market is being driven by demand for supplies to combat Covid-19, but growth will return to normal once the pandemic subsides. Government relief packages throughout the pandemic will not provide long-term support to the market.

East African governments, as well as lenders, will increasingly aim to increase the financial sustainability of rail projects. As a result, we expect some standard gauge railway (SGR) projects to be substituted with less expensive rehabilitations of existing narrow gauge railways and remaining SGR projects to attract international contractors and financiers with perceived stricter loan

July 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Netherlands 5G Spectrum Auction: High Prices For Small Market

The Netherlands has completed its initial 5G spectrum auction, raising EUR1.23bn. Bids were relatively high, reflecting the three incumbents' robust IoT pedigrees. The risk is that they may have overpaid in an effort to secure access to a small industrial IoT market.

T-Mobile appears to have come off worst in the auction, securing 70MHz.

Source: Company Website

July 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Covid-19 Funding Will Create Commercial Opportunities For Medical Devices In The Philippines

Despite an expected economic recession in the Philippines in 2020, which will pose headwinds to the medical device market, commercial opportunities are still on the rise. Funding from the Philippines Charity Sweepstakes Office (PCSO), as well as the Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corporation (PAGCOR), will provide opportunities for medical device manufacturers and suppliers.

Source: Company Website

July 23: Business Monitor International Inc.: Off-Trade Coffee Spending Boosted By Covid-19 Pandemic

At Fitch Solutions, we believe that consumer spending on coffee (through retail channels) will receive a significant boost in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. We project consumer spending on coffee globally to increase by 5.8% y-o-y (in US dollar terms) in 2020, which is significantly up from the estimated growth of 0.1% y-o-y in 2019 and the average annual growth rate of 1.0% over 2.

Source: Company Website

July 22: Business Monitor International Inc.: Pent-Up Investor Demand Paving Way For Smaller Brazilian Floats

Despite being home to one of the world's largest stock exchanges, Brazil has struggled to record a strong flow of IPO activity over recent years. We believe that deal levels on the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange (or commonly known as the Bovespa bourse) will also remain low in the near term, with the country expected to see a forecast sharp contraction in economic growth in 2020. At Fitch Solutions, we forecast the Brazilian econ.

Source: Company Website

Japan's push to reduce its industries' reliance on Chinese manufacturing by subsidising the relocation of manufacturing facilities out of China and not only back to Japan, but also into the wider South East Asia region, will greatly benefit countries in South East Asia. One of the key themes that emerged from this first round of incentives is that the manufacturing of steel c.

Targeted regional lockdown in Spain as new infection doubled post nationwide lockdown. ROVI's facility in Madrid to manufacture Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine candidate. 95% of Spain's population remains susceptible to Covid-19 virus.

July 15: Business Monitor International Inc.: Asia Autos Production: Japan Regains Second Place, But Is Not Without Challenges

In the most recent update of our Autos Production RRI, the Asia region's overall score has remained stable at 56.2 out of a possible 100. As such, the region maintains its position as the most attractive region for vehicle production globally, followed by Europe (53.8) and the Americas (43.4). SECTION 5 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

We have revised our Myanmar thermal capacity forecasts to account for the progress of several gas-fired projects under emergency tenders. While these projects have faced delays and missed their operational deadlines as we expected, progress will mean that they are likely to still come online within two years, by a conservative estimate.

March 19: Business Monitor International Inc.: Gym And Fitness Subscription A Trend To Watch In China, Despite Covid-19 Outbreak

A large youth population, expanding wealth and increasing health awareness are the demand drivers behind the gym and fitness-as-a-subscription services (yoga, spin, boxing) expansion in China. While this sector has struggled during the Covid-19 (coronavirus) outbreak, we believe that this will be a short term dampening to this trend, as the underlying fundamentals remain in place. Operators remain focused on deploying advanced mobile data services in Sub-Saharan Africa, but driving uptake and monetisation remain long-term plays. Facing highly competitive operating environments, players will focus on boosting their spectrum assets and ensuring superior network quality and reach as competitive differentiators.

On June 30, Fitch Solutions held a webinar, 'Commodities After-Covid-19: Trends And Opportunities', in which we discussed the short-term impact of the pandemic on commodities prices and long-term implications for the agribusiness and mining & metals sectors. In this article, we answer some of the most asked questions received during the webinar's Q&A session.

The Covid-19 pandemic poses an unprecedented threat to Argentina's vehicle output as it causes disruption to production while also dampening the demand for new vehicles. July 15: Business Monitor International Inc.: Asia Autos Production: Japan Regains Second Place, But Is Not Without Challenges

In the most recent update of our Autos Production RRI, the Asia region's overall score has remained stable at 56.2 out of a possible 100. As such, the region maintains its position as the most attractive region for vehicle production globally, followed by Europe (53.8) and the Americas (43.4). The Asia region benefits from major automotive countries, such as China, Japan and India, all having large volume vehicle production, healthy completion, a good pool of skilled labour and strong automotive policies. However, production growth scores in these markets have fallen due to the spread of Covid-19. We highlight that Japan is not shielded from suppressed output amid the pandemic, which means that its overall score is being held back by its performance under our 'Vehicle production growth' indicator on our Risk/Reward Index.

SECTION 5 BUSINESS MONITOR INTERNATIONAL INC. TOP MANAGEMENT

Richard Hall, CEO

Richard was appointed in June 2014 following the acquisition of Business Monitor International (now BMI Research) by the Fitch Group. Under his leadership BMI Research is poised for a new period of global growth which will benefit clients and contribute to Fitch's preeminence in financial and business information services. Before joining BMI, Richard spent eight years as COO at Mergermarket Limited where he created and launched Debtwire and dealReporter prior to its sale to Pearson Plc and earnout period. More recently, he was COO of WorldOne Limited where he played a key role in transforming the company from an entrepreneurial business to one poised for future growth. He is currently Non-executive Chairman of Cognolink Limited. Richard has an MA in Economics from the University of Cambridge and an MBA from INSEAD.

urn:contentItem:60GR-YST1-DXKH-N26J-00000-00July 31, 2020: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: "Check Your Grandparents' Stock Portfolios"2020-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 31, 2020: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: "Check Your Grandparents' Stock Portfolios"

Tony, John, and Brendan discuss Big Tech's antitrust hearing & Q2 earnings, national security issues in the pharmaceutical supply chain, and this week's FOMC meeting. They also talk about where negotiations stand on a phase four coronavirus relief bill.

INDEX

SECTION 1 HAMILTON PLACE STRATEGIES, LLC PROFILE

SECTION 2 OTHER NEWS: 2020

SECTION 3 PRESS RELEASES: 2019

SECTION 4 OTHER NEWS: 2019

SECTION 1 HAMILTON PLACE STRATEGIES, LLC PROFILE

1.1 ACTIVITIES

Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC provides communications, policy, and advocacy consulting services. It offers news cycle and crisis management, public relations, research, and coalition building and management services. The company provides objective and actionable analysis services for business and political dynamics and economic policy. It develops strategic and crisis communications campaigns and plans. Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC is based in Washington, District Of Columbia.

1.2 SUMMARY

PermID: 5040947205

Website: http://www.hamiltonplacestrategies.com

Industry: Miscellaneous Commercial Services and Supplies

SECTION 2 OTHER NEWS: 2020

July 24: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: This Is The Alamo

John Dick, Founder and CEO of Civic Science, joins Tony, John, and Brendan to discuss the latest economic sentiment index readings-from price sensitivity and savings, to the end of unemployment insurance payments. The guys also discuss the market's response to increasing COVID cases across the country, the pitfalls of the Main Street Lending Program, and the latest on European stimulus. Finally, the crew previews Fed interest rate news, Q2 GDP numbers, and earnings for the tech giants coming up next week.

Source: Company Website

July 22: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: Podcast Series: An Education On The Hard Realities Facing Higher Ed

In a new episode of HPS Insights' special series on higher education we talk to Matt Perault, Director of the Center on Science & Technology Policy and former Head of Global Policy Development at Facebook. Matt joins Stacy and Elliott to discuss synergies between the technology and education worlds and innovation in higher education in the time of COVID-19. They dive into the contributions that universities are making to public policy and discuss tech regulation on the horizon.

On the third episode of HPS Insights' special series on higher education, Stacy, Matt, and Elliott host Dr. Debbie Cottrell, President of Texas Lutheran University in Seguin, Texas. Dr. Cottrell joins the podcast to discuss her role as the head administrator at a small, private university and the behind-the-scenes planning of students' eventual return to campus after the COVID-19 pandemic. The team discusses the economic effects of the pandemic on the higher education sector, how policymakers can take an active role in supporting students, and the true costs of higher education with endowments, financial aid, and complex pricing models.

Source: Company Website

July 17: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: A Tale Of Two Economies

To cap off a relatively "normal" week, Tony, John, and Brendan talk through what we've learned so far from Q2 earnings and how they represent the divergence in how companies have fared during the pandemic. The gang also takes a global look at the European economy, ECB fiscal stimulus, and how U.S.-China tensions have evolved from trade disputes to cultural confrontation. Plus, they take a look ahead to upcoming earnings.

Source: Company Website

July 10: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: The End Of The Beginning

Matt, John, and Brendan discuss the state of play with initial government-run pandemic relief programs wrapping up and take a look at how the "real" economy in America is doing at this moment in time. The guys also talk about the 2020 presidential race and preview upcoming Q2 earnings.

Source: Company Website

July 02: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: "A Tale Of Two Jobs Reports"

Tony, John, and Brendan break down another interesting jobs report and try to make sense of what it means for the state of the economy. The gang also plays a game of "known knowns and known unknowns" to try to figure out what we can expect in the weeks and months ahead for schools, fiscal support, the economic recovery, and even politics.

Source: Company Website

May 27: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: A Conversation With Kate Andersen Brower On "Team Of Five"

HPS Partners Stacy Kerr and Michael Steel are joined by New York Times bestselling author Kate Andersen Brower to discuss her newest book, "Team of Five: The Presidents Club in the Age of Trump." They discuss the collegial relationships and norms for presidents and how the former presidents view their roles during the Trump administration. Plus, Kate offers a behind-the-scenes look into the private bonds between the former American leaders.

Source: Company Website

May 08: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: A Historic Jobs Day

On this Jobs Day episode of the HPS Macrocast, Tony, Matt, John, and Brendan unpack the historic jobs numbers, discuss near-term stabilization in oil markets, and dive into what to expect in upcoming relief package negotiations in Washington. They also discuss potential long-term effects of COVID-19 on remote work policies and the future of the leisure and hospitality industry.

Source: Company Website

May 06: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: Oil's New Refrain: "Don't Drill Baby, Drill"

HPS Managing Director Stratton Kirton and Associate Bryce Campanelli join Managing Director Bryan DeAngelis to discuss their recent analysis on global and domestic oil markets. As oil producers are pumping millions more barrels of oil each day than the market needs, and storage is running out, Stratton and Bryce explain the short- and long-term economic and policy impacts.

Source: Company Website

April 23: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC : Viruses Know No Borders: COVID-19 & The Developing World

HPS Partner Tony Fratto hosts President & Editor-in-Chief of Devex Raj Kumar to discuss the impact of the coronavirus on the developing world. The two cover the unique challenges that developing nations face confronting the coronavirus, the global nature of the pandemic, and the effect of oil prices on all of this. They also discuss Raj's new book "The Business of Changing the World."

Source: Company Website

April 17: We are Gonna Need A Trillion Dollars

Tony, John, and Brendan discuss the Paycheck Protection Program, bank earnings, and jobs numbers. The crew also talks about lessons from remote work and what reopening the economy might look like.

Source: Company Website

April 10: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: Tossing Around Trillions

Tony, John, and Brendan break down the Federal Reserve's broad efforts to help the economy, including new lending programs and supporting riskier debt. They also discuss the latest OPEC deal, the impacts of growing public and private debt, and additional stimulus on the horizon.

Source: Company Website

April 08: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: I Was Supposed To Be On Spring Break

On this week's bonus episode, Tony and the Markets Policy gang discuss the COVID-19 outbreak's impact on markets, small business relief, and the Eurozone's response to the crisis. They also look at how crude oil is impacting markets and how to approach data during these uncertain times.

Source: Company Website

February 13: HPS Announces New Director Michael Michaud And Promotions For Stratton Kirton, Stephanie Walstrom, And Julie Sarne

Hamilton Place Strategies (HPS) announced today that Michael Michaud has joined the firm as Director. The team also promoted current employees Stratton Kirton, Stephanie Walstrom, and Julie Sarne to Managing Director, Senior Director, and Director, respectively.

"I'm excited to welcome Michael to the HPS team," said Tony Fratto, HPS founding partner. "Michael brings with him an incredibly deep knowledge of the financial services sector. I'm looking forward to seeing him translate his expertise to help our clients navigate the complex challenges they face."

Michaud joins HPS from the boutique investment bank Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, where he served as Assistant Vice President. This role placed him at the intersection of policy and financial services sectors, requiring him to closely analyze the effects of past and proposed regulation and legal settlements on the financial services industry. Previously, Michaud worked at MLB Productions, where he used custom software to catalogue events at MLB games in real time for use in MLB broadcasts.

HPS is also excited to announce the promotions of Stratton Kirton to Managing Director, Stephanie Walstrom to Senior Director, and Julie Sarne to Director.

"Stratton, Stephanie, and Julie have been such important contributions to our success," said Tony Fratto.

January 15: HPS Names Jim David Partner

Today, Hamilton Place Strategies (HPS) announced that Jim David has been named partner at the firm.

For the past three years, Jim has served as a managing director at HPS, providing strategic counsel to major corporations, investment firms, and trade associations on a range of complex matters. In particular, Jim has helped to lead and grow the firm's work in high-profile mergers and acquisitions, litigation, and regulatory crises.

"I'm thrilled to welcome Jim as a partner at HPS. He is already a highly-valued team member who cares deeply about the firm's ability to innovate and grow to better serve our clients, and he has invested meaningfully in the success of all our colleagues," said HPS Partner Matt McDonald. "Jim has continuously executed creative and successful communications strategies in high-stakes situations for many of our clients. We value his leadership, talent, and continued dedication to improving our firm."

Prior to joining HPS, Jim was a managing director at Kekst and Company in New York, a public relations firm, where he worked with Fortune 500 companies, leading alternative asset managers, and others on landmark merger and acquisition, bankruptcy, and activist shareholder assignments.

January 10: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: Jobs Day From The Quiet Car

On the first episode of season two, HPS partner Matt McDonald joins Tony and John in D.C. to discuss new Jobs Day numbers and comments from former Federal Reserve chairs Ben Bernanke and Janet Yellen at the American Economic Association's annual meetings in San Diego. The guys also discuss the global market effects of tensions between the United States and Iran, and look forward to all that's to come in 2020.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 3 PRESS RELEASES: 2019

December 10: HPS Launches Analysis Practice

Hamilton Place Strategies (HPS) today announced the formation of a new Analysis Practice within the firm. This new practice will serve as a formal platform for the research and analytics foundation that has long been the source of innovation for HPS in public affairs consulting.

"Our clients are wrestling with the challenge of increasingly complex issues and increasing levels of public scrutiny at the same time. A command of research, data, and analysis is a prerequisite to effective public affairs today," said HPS Partner Matt McDonald. "This practice will ensure we continue leading original, compelling campaigns, enhancing understanding of issues, and pushing the boundaries of our work."

HPS Senior Director Lloyd Miller has been named as the first head of the Analysis Practice, bringing a range of technical and programming skills to traditional HPS strengths across research, data, and policy expertise. The focus of the Analysis Practice will be to enhance public affairs through research that is rigorous, accessible, and thought provoking. Changing minds on issues and improving decisions in public policy and business requires an evidenced-based approach that allows expert audiences to understand complex situations from multiple perspectives.

HPS will continue building effective campaigns by incorporating new applications for trusted analytical approaches, identifying and structuring data from across sources, and telling compelling stories backed by original research and creative visualizations.

Source: Company Website

June 06: HPS Welcomes Christina Pearson as Managing Director

WASHINGTON, D.C. ' Hamilton Place Strategies (HPS) is proud to announce veteran public affairs strategist Christina Pearson has joined the firm's Washington, D.C. office as a managing director.

Pearson brings to HPS her deep experience working on some of the most consequential technology and healthcare debates of the last two decades.

'I couldn't be more excited to have Christina join us,' said Tony Fratto, founding partner of HPS. 'Christina is one of the most talented communicators I've ever worked with. She has such wonderful judgment, she works on very complex issues, and she's a leader. The areas where Christina has spent most of her career ' technology and healthcare ' are growing sectors of our business at HPS and her leadership will be invaluable.'

'Most importantly, Christina is a wonderful person and colleague. I've seen how she works to elevate the work of her colleagues, and that's an important part of our culture at HPS. We're very lucky that Christina chose to continue her career with us,' said Fratto.

Pearson said, 'HPS provides a unique blend of expertise, culture, creativity, and emphasis on an analytical approach to public affairs. These principles are the foundation of great strategic work that makes a difference. I couldn't be more delighted to start the next chapter of my career with this amazing team.'

For nearly a decade before joining HPS, Pearson directed communications for Microsoft's government and public policy initiatives as senior director of public affairs. In that role, she elevated the voice of the company and its executives on key technology, education, and privacy issues, integrating new technologies and data-driven messaging to build support for and showcase the tangible benefits of smart policies in these areas.

Prior to Microsoft, Pearson served as Assistant Secretary of Public Affairs at the U.S.

SECTION 4 OTHER NEWS: 2019

December 27: Hamilton Place Strategies, LLC: Bonus Macrocast: How Did We Get Here?

On a bonus episode of the Macrocast, Tony, John, and Brendan discuss their career paths, how they ended up together, and why they set out to do the Macrocast. The gang also gives tips on where to get news and who to watch in macroeconomics, as well as a few good reads for the holiday break.

Source: Company Website

September 17: A Note From Tony Fratto On HPS' 10-Year Anniversary

When you start a business during an economic recession and financial crisis, the risk is that you spend much more time thinking about the next six months than you do about the next ten years. But one of the things I'm proud of at Hamilton Place Strategies is that from the very beginning, we were focused on building a durable business - focused more on the unique quality of our work than on any individual or any political moment in time.

Ten years ago, the landscape for all firms was changing. Big issues facing firms were becoming increasingly complex, public, and global. At the same time, news organizations covering these very complex issues were devoting more resources to sophisticated reporting and presentation of news. The ability to share this news was growing as well. The kinds of deep, wonky analysis usually reserved for think tanks was now showing up on popular news sites.

Working in that news environment requires a much greater depth of knowledge about the issues and challenges facing firms. We felt that analytical, evidence-based messaging, strategies, and tactics would be most effective.

We also felt that for HPS to be a credible participant on these issues - and a partner to our clients - it was also important to show our analysis and express our views, regardless of ideology, party, or politics.

July 16: HPS Announces Claire Bischoff as Director: HPS Announces Claire Bischoff as Director

Today, Hamilton Place Strategies (HPS) is pleased to announce Claire Bischoff's promotion to director at the firm.

Since joining HPS in 2016, Claire has performed invaluable work as an associate and senior associate, helping to develop and implement strategic communications, crisis management, and brand development strategies for clients in finance, mergers and acquisitions, and tech, among other industries. Throughout her time at the firm, Claire also helped scale HPS's design capabilities through her knowledge of graphics tools and user experience design. Most notably, Claire led a full rebrand of HPS' affiliate company, Flag Media Analytics.

Claire recently returned from a four-month rotation in HPS' New York office, where she helped expand the HPS approach beyond the Beltway and portfolio in communications challenges surrounding transactions, crises, thought-leadership, and other complex issues in highly-regulated sectors.

"From day one, Claire has proven herself to be a natural leader and a creative thinker," said HPS founding partner Tony Fratto. "It has been a great pleasure to watch her grow and the impact she's had over the last three years with our clients and our teams.

July 13: HPS Welcomes Class of 2019 Associates

Hamilton Place Strategies (HPS) is pleased to congratulate the class of 2019 on their recent and upcoming graduations and is excited to welcome the HPS class of 2019 Associates and Analysts to the firm.

Tala Anchassi - Georgetown University Carolyn Backus - Washington University in St. Louis Natalia Cooper - Howard University Aye Diallo - Howard University Oliver Edelmann - University of Virginia Koby Gordon - Dartmouth College Alexa Green - Dartmouth College Daniel Grossman - University of Michigan So Jung Kim - University of Michigan Cole Kline - George Washington University Claire Radler - University of Notre Dame Matisse Rogers - University of Michigan Adeline Sandridge - University of Virginia Ellie Turner - Washington University in St. Louis Brandon Velez - University of Virginia

The Associate and Analyst program is an integral part of HPS' commitment to recruiting top talent to deliver the best possible outcomes for clients. Recruiting takes place each fall, and new hires join after graduation the following year.

"This is our fifth year of on-campus recruiting, and our applicants continue to have incredibly compelling academic, professional, and personal backgrounds," said HPS Partner Matt McDonald.

urn:contentItem:5WPX-XVF1-JB20-G2MK-00000-00July Jobs Report Out Today; Trump Planning Additional Tariffs on $300 Billion Worth of Chinese Goods at 10 Percent; North Korea Launches Two More Short-Range Missiles; Senate Passes Two Year Government Spending Bill; WSJ: New Tax Plan Could Give Companies Incentive To Stay To U.S.; Puerto Rico Governor Leaving Office Without Successor In Place; Deadly Gas Explosion; Washington Plane Lands On Highway; Minnesota Drive-Through Ban Vote; From Media To Marijuana2019-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTJoanie Courtney, John Lonski, Ann Berry, Grover Norquist, Tony HunterNEWSFinancial080201cb.231July Jobs Report Out Today; Trump Planning Additional Tariffs on $300 Billion Worth of Chinese Goods at 10 Percent; North Korea Launches Two More Short-Range Missiles; Senate Passes Two Year Government Spending Bill; WSJ: New Tax Plan Could Give Companies Incentive To Stay To U.S.; Puerto Rico Governor Leaving Office Without Successor In Place; Deadly Gas Explosion; Washington Plane Lands On Highway; Minnesota Drive-Through Ban Vote; From Media To MarijuanaMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: It sure is, ladies, thank you so much. Big show ahead, good morning, everyone, happy Friday, I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Friday, August 2nd, your top stories right now, just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

U.S.-China trade turmoil today, President Trump threatens to impose a 10 percent tariff on another $300 billion on Chinese goods. The move could affect prices, at a slew of things, including smartphones, clothing, toys, now, China is vowing retaliation.

Markets are lower, Futures extending yesterday's declines right now. We are expecting a pressure -- some pressure on the market this morning, down about 87 points right now. Markets are turning sharply lower, as soon as the President tweeted the tariff threat yesterday, ending down in the triple digits. Yesterday, global markets took cue from the U.S., trading lower today.

Yesterday's close down almost 300 points, and the FT 100 is down 142, CAC Quarante is down 155, and the DAX Index in Germany, down 300 points right now.

In Asia overnight, it was red across the board there, as well, due to the trade concerns. As you see, worst performer was Japan, as well as Hong Kong down better than two percent a piece.

Plus, jobs in America, investors waiting on the July jobs report today, economists are expecting 164,000 jobs added to the economy last month, with the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.7 percent. We've got special coverage, all hands on deck, 8:00 a.m. Eastern.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

BARTIROMO: And we've got a big show this morning, joining the conversation this morning, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Moody's Capital Markets chief economist, John Lonski is here, and Employbridge chief workforce analyst, Joanie Courtney. It is great to see everybody this morning.

JOANIE COURTNEY, CHIEF WORKFORCE ANALYST, EMPLOYBRIDGE: Good morning, glad to be here.

BARTIROMO: We've got a big show coming up, a lot of market impacts. Also on deck this morning, joining the conversation, Americans for Tax Reform president and founder, Grover Norquist is here. I want to talk about spending and the budget with Grover. Pennsylvania congressman, House Judiciary and Armed Services Committee member, Guy Reschenthaler is here, on the INF Treaty and Iran.

Plus, former Chicago Tribune publisher, Revolution Enterprises chairman, Tony Hunter, joining us this morning to talk big business of marijuana, wait until you see what he's doing.

Then, family medicine doctor, Mikhail Varshavski, aka Dr. Mike, joining us to talk about the health benefits of plant-based burgers with all the hype around Impossible burger, we're going to talk about that. Don't miss a moment of it, big three hours this morning.

And, of course, our top story today is President Trump's tariff threat, hitting markets yesterday. Futures pointing to a decline at the start of trading this morning, again, extending yesterday's declines, down another 80 points. It comes after a wild day yesterday.

You can see the down slide just after President Trump announced that he is probably going to slap China with 10 percent tariff on the remaining $300 billion worth of goods. We've been waiting for the president's action on this remaining 325 billion in goods coming in from China.

And he told us what he's going to do (INAUDIBLE) can go all the way up to 25, but he's doing 10 percent. The action would hit consumers in a new way, taxing everyday products, like shoes, toys, smartphones, televisions, computers, it's going to get expensive, President Trump commenting on the move last night, at a campaign rally in Ohio.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We've taken the toughest- ever action to stand up to China's straight abuse, and I just announced another 10 percent tariff on $300 billion worth of Chinese products that come into our country.

For the last 20 years, China has taken hundreds and hundreds of billions of dollars out of our country, and now, we are stopping the theft of American jobs, we're stopping the theft of so many other things happening, including intellectual property.

President Xi is a good man, he's a friend of mine, he understands it. And until such time, as there is a deal, we will be taxing the hell out of China.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And that begins on September 1, with these new tariffs. Guys, let's talk about this because this is obviously going to move markets again today, John, your reaction?

JOHN LONSKI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S CAPITAL MARKETS: You know, we got off to a good start yesterday, these news on tariffs came out, the market sell -- sold off deeply. This issue has been with us now for more than a year. It started June 2018.

It hasn't helped the economy. We would've had faster than three percent growth for the first time since 2005, had it not been for tariffs in 2018. I don't think it's helping the president, politically, and it's definitely hurting the U.S., economically.

BARTIROMO: Actually, you make a good point because that's the angle of the Journal took today, in the op-ed, talking about this, saying these tariffs have been in place now, 18 months, and one of the uncertainties here, one of the problems, is that nobody knows when they're going to stop, Dagen, I mean, you don't know where this is going.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right, you have CEOs across the country that are sitting around watching the president's Twitter feed, all day long, rather than actually running businesses and creating jobs.

And, again, when you talk about job creation in this country and long-term investment decisions, and it was business spending that dragged down economic growth in the second quarter, you have people sitting around saying we can't plan because we don't know what's going to happen in terms of our imports from China or even the global manufacturing picture.

Again, this isn't -- this -- our tariffs hurt China and doesn't hurt anyone else, that the Journal points out in that very op-ed, that they've hurt -- our fight with China and the tariffs, it hurt U.S. exports and contributed to what is close to a global recession in manufacturing. This is not good.

We've talked about on this program, just in recent weeks, as long as we had the status quo of there are additional tariffs at this point, that they continue to negotiate with the United States, I'm talking about China, that it could, at least, stabilize the environment here, in the U.S., for the economy, but there -- and -- then, yesterday, boom.

And there's been a huge rust to treasuries. People are buying treasuries, sending the yield on the 10-year down even lower this morning, ahead of the jobs report.

BARTIROMO: Yes, part of the issue here is that China keeps reneging on everything, I mean, it's not just the fact that they refuse to put law in place, in China, that it is unlawful to steal intellectual property, but it's also the moves on the currency.

It's the moves with the investment and forced transfer of technology, all these things that are manufactured from China, to actually just dominate, and that's one of the things, obviously, those talks broke down in Shanghai, and there was no giving in on the China side.

COURTNEY: Right. And, you know, Maria, I thought it was really interesting. President Trump's comments on the White House lawn yesterday, he also spoke about how President Xi had gone back on stopping Fentanyl from coming into the country.

BARTIROMO: That's another issue. That's right.

COURTNEY: He also said that he was going to, you know, start buying from the farmers, that hasn't happened, so there's many things at play here, but, I think, to Dagen's point, it really is impacting the confidence of CEOs, and they're feeling, you know, that yes, we're going to make those hires.

It definitely is impacting the job market because employers are cautious, they are going to be cautious until they see what happens.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's the impact on CapEx, like you said, and that's the angle in the Journal as well, the fact that we don't know where this is going. This uncertainty is going to, once again, push managers, businesses, CEOs, to sit on cash. That's what we saw in the GDP. CapEx was down in that last GDP, right?

MCDOWELL: Right. And don't just sit -- CEOs are going to sit around, and if not -- and not making investment decisions, start laying off people. I'll point to Lowe's. Lowe's is unique -- a unique company, but what's the story in the Journal today, that Lowe's has told that it's basically laying off thousands of people. That it's going to outsource the assembly of goods and its stores.

They're offering them other jobs in the stores, but again, you're going to see a lot more of that if this -- if this continues.

LONSKI: There's no going back on globalization. You know, many U.S.-based corporations conduct manufacturing out of China. Look at Apple. Look at the problems that this is going to present for Apple if he follows through on this threat to increase tariffs.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but John, I mean, the fact is --I say this all of the time, I mean, for so many years, CEOs were so interested in getting a foothold in China, to be able to sell their products to the 1.4 billion people there, that they forgot to protect their own products.

I mean, you know, Secretary Pompeo has made this point a lot. You want to go operate in China, go with your eyes open, because they will steal from you, and they will copy everything that you have.

LONSKI: Don't you think the CEOs should have known better? I mean --

BARTIROMO: They did. That was -- yes, all they wanted to do was expand their markets, and they didn't recognize what the threat was, really, as China was rising and rising and rising, and using their military to really be front and center.

They want to become the number one super power, militarily, that's one of the issues, and they are ahead of us in a number of technology issues, arguably, A.I.

LONSKI: And to Trump's credit, he brought this issue to the forefront.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: I was going to add to that. He recognized the destruction of Middle America and good-paying stable jobs in this country, which happened, literally, over decades. He recognized that. He spoke to those individuals. However, he started a fight that he will not be able to settle by the time voters go to polls next year.

The danger is, the economy continues to weaken, which it is, so far, this year. And then when that people go to polls, the economy is at or near a recession, and he will not get re-elected if that's the backdrop.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point. And jobs in America is the focus today, we got the jobs number out this morning. Investors are waiting on the July number, out in just over two hours. We're expecting 164,000 jobs to have been added to the economy in the month of July. We are expecting the unemployment rate to hold steady at 3.7 percent.

Joanie, what are you looking for, what's most important to you from this report this morning?

COURTNEY: Yes, you know, I think it's going to be important, of course, to look at revisions for May and June, to see whether the numbers move because, obviously, we all know June was such a strong report. Wages are going to be really important, labor participation, also, very important to look at.

But, I expect we are going to see a good job report. We have over 7 million open jobs in the country, 6 million unemployed people. There definitely is a strong demand. It's going to come back to where employers, you know, number one, confident to make those hires.

And number two, were they able to find the skill and talent to meet that demand, because we still have a skill's gap issue, as we've talked about before, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we sure do.

COURTNEY: And still a big challenge.

BARTIROMO: John, what are you looking for?

LONSKI: Like you said, you know, we have, like, a million more job openings than we have unemployed. It's a pretty good market, we had a very strong reading on consumer confidence for the month of July, 170,000 new jobs, that's close to the average monthly increase for the second quarter.

You know, keep a special eye on the private-sector jobs growth, that's a little bit less, running under 160,000. Wage growth three-tenths of a percent, up year-to-year 3.2 percent.

BARTIROMO: 3.2 percent.

LONSKI: For wages.

MCDOWELL: And manufacturing, really quickly, 5,000 gains expected in manufacturing, if that comes in light that could rattle markets even further.

BARTIROMO: And that's where the weakness has been. We even saw a weaker PMI in Chicago this week. We've been looking at the PMIs, Purchasing Managers' tells us the whole story.

LONSKI: Worse reading sets that slump we had in manufacturing and business sales back in 2015, 2016, so keep an eye on that, I mean, if we ever further slowing of business sales, especially outside of the energy sector, then we're going to begin to, perhaps, have problems fairly soon on the job's front.

Capital spending, as we mentioned earlier, is already suffering from the sharp deceleration by business sales. And eventually, this could find its way into hiring activity.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll see. Well, that's exactly what's playing out in the markets this morning. All of these concerns that you all have just brought up, has the markets under pressure once again.

We'll take a short break. Then, we're going to turn our attentions to the tensions flurrying out with North Korea, it is launching two more short- range missiles, how the U.S. is responding to that. And then, Facebook, continues under the microscope, why the FTC is taking a closer look at the social media giant's acquisitions now, stock is under pressure this morning.

We'll be right back with a lot more, right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, North Korea apparently firing two more missiles, Cheryl Casone on headlines now. Good morning, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. Well, according to South Korean officials, short-range North Korean missiles were fired into the sea of the Eastern Coast. This is North Korea's third round of weapons testing in just over a week. The launch is seen as a way to increase pressure on Seoul and Washington over these stalled nuclear talks.

Well, back here at home, Boeing, planning further changes to the flight control software on its 737 Max jets. The redesign involving using both flight-controlled computers, instead of just one computer. Boeing already has announced initial changes to the system, overall, of course, linked to those two deadly crashes. Shares of Boeing, low in premarket, down a little more than half a percent right now.

Well, earning season continues this morning, with trouble at Toyota, the company cutting its profit forecast for the full year by nearly six percent due to the strong yen. The yen has been strengthening amid global trade tensions, and then, Honda's bottom line, also taking a hit, on lower U.S. car sales, company's first quarter profit, falling by 16 percent.

And then, there is Pinterest, the stock is actually higher in the premarket right now, their latest results coming in better-than-expected. Pinterest is also raising guidance for 2019. There is Pinterest, Maria, in the premarket, down a little -- excuse me, higher by almost 17 percent and, of course, we are waiting on two Dow components this morning as well, managing sectors, so it's another big morning for earnings.

BARTIROMO: It sure is. Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: You mentioned the Yen, I know Jon Hilsenrath's going to bring up the dollar. We're going to talk about that as well, because this is all getting impacted here, and part of the story for earnings, as well as these markets.

We'll take a break. When we come back, the Dow's wild day yesterday, markets taking a dive after President Trump's tweets on tariffs, 10 percent on that 300 plus billion from China.

We showed you the mustard-flavored ice cream yesterday. Meanwhile, Oscar Mayer's new flavor is a perfect compliment. We're going to check that out today, ahead of National Mustard Day tomorrow, back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets are lower this morning on top of yesterday's big selloff. Check Futures, Dow Futures down 45, S&P Futures down 7, NASDAQ Futures down 35, markets declining for second day in a row on news that President Trump is planning to put in place new tariffs on China, beginning September 1st.

Joining us right now is Cornell Capital partner, Ann Berry. And Ann, it is good to have you on the program this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

ANN BERRY, PARTNER, CORNELL CAPITAL: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: The impact on investing, from your standpoint, to all of this?

BERRY: Well, I think, what we're going to continue to see is companies rattling to figure out now what to do with supply chains. I think, you know, up until yesterday, there was some assumption that we, at least, at the point of stability. And the time has come to start planning to, maybe, redirect production out of China, or I think this has, sort of, throwing that -- throwing that into haywire a little bit.

BARTIROMO: So, the supply chain getting disrupted is a big deal, right? I mean, we've seen a handful of companies announced they're going to move their production out of China, going to Vietnam. That's not an easy thing to do. Tell us how you see this playing out.

BERRY: It's definitely (INAUDIBLE) if you look at Apple, for example, there was a lot of speculation they'd stop moving their supply chain quite quickly. And then, you know, reports came out, it'll probably take 3 years just to move 15 percent of their supply chain base. It's a very big investment, it takes a long time.

I think, in this instance, businesses will be trying to anticipate with more change coming, and this is the time to move, or will they sit tight and wait to how this plays out?

BARTIROMO: There's a feeling -- there was a talk yesterday, on Wall Street, maybe you guys heard it, that now, there's this competition between the tariff situation and the Fed, that maybe the president wasn't happy with Jay Powell's moves yesterday.

And Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell said that the Central Bank will monitor global growth and trade policy uncertainty. Could the new tariffs be a push to get Powell to cut rates bigger and faster?

MCDOWELL: That would be the most insane thing on the planet.

BARTIROMO: That would be insane. But people were talking about this yesterday on trading desks.

MCDOWELL: That would be a -- like, that would be a world of insanity that I can't even get my head around. Because, again, it's like, what's more -- it would -- that's the essential question, is another rate cut going to offset the decline in business spending, right, John? The Journal writes about it today.

LONSKI: Who knows? There may be some truth of this semi-madness, but I'd look, you know, this morning. The Futures market assigns 90 percent odds to a rate cut at the September 18th meeting, the next meeting of the FOMC, and by the end of the year, 75 percent odds, a Fed funds being no higher than 1.63 percent.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And look at the selloff we got on the 25 basis point cut earlier this week. Investors wanted 50 basis points.

MCDOWELL: So, the tariff threat, it's not a threat. The plan, yesterday, announced by President Trump, it has driven longer-term interest rates lower for the central question among the likes of John Lonski is, will lower borrowing costs basically wipe away the investment shield, the business investment shield of the trade uncertainty, and many said no.

COURTNEY: But there was -- it was -- it was so interesting. There was so much news yesterday, obviously, following this, because there was a lot of talk in the morning about Powell's comments and certainly, that he was, like, very, like, middle of the road, noncommittal about whether they were going to be aggressively cutting rates, you know, throughout the year. Like, he really played it off that way.

Then, obviously --

LONSKI: The press conference.

COURTNEY: -- the press conference. And we hear about the tariffs with China, so it was interesting timing, so I understand why people were really talking about that, but it speaks to uncertainty --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

COURTNEY: -- in the market.

(CROSSTALK)

LONSKI: You know, this might provide a little bit of a lift to the consumer. Last four weeks, applications for mortgage re-financings are up 85 percent --

BARTIROMO: Wow, 85 percent.

LONSKI: -- year-over-year. That's incredible, and applications for the purchase of home, mortgage applications for home buying, up six percent, perhaps home buying will come alive.

COURTNEY: That also is -- has jumped up quite a bit, almost --

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, we keep seeing that in all the reports. Ann, jump in here, because we've got the consumer strengthening, but business is holding back and pushing back on CapEx.

HUNTER: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Tony Hunter. We'll be right back.

urn:contentItem:5W8P-CFP1-JDVW-N11R-00000-00June 1 renewals pricing; Everest cuts retro buy; NFIP extended through September2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisExclusiveJune 1 renewals pricing; Everest cuts retro buy; NFIP extended through SeptemberRJ Dumaual

Reinsurance pricing for loss-affected accounts reportedly increased 10% to 30% on average at the June 1 renewals. Also, New Zealand's Earthquake Commission secured NZ$6.2 billion of reinsurance coverage.

Morgan Stanley analysts estimated that reinsurance pricing for loss-affected accounts increased 10% to 30% on average at the June 1 renewals, Business Insurance reported. Based on conversations with reinsurers, loss-free accounts were renewing flat to up 10%, while retrocessional capacity was "limited."

Florida-based Heritage Insurance Holdings Inc.'s 2019-2020 catastrophe reinsurance program is its largest ever, with the first event reinsurance exhaustion point increased to $1.5 billion and the cost of the cover declining to $249.2 million from $259.5 million in the prior year.

New Zealand's Earthquake Commission secured NZ$6.2 billion of reinsurance coverage for the 12 months beginning June 1, online news portal Stuff reported. The amount is higher than the NZ$5.55 billion in protection secured in the prior year. The reinsurance will be used for claims stemming from earthquakes, tsunami and volcanic eruptions, among others.

Meanwhile, Everest Re Group Ltd. rowed back its retrocessional cover purchase to as little as $150 million, having initially been in the market for what some sources said was up to $900 million, The Insurance Insider reported.

An extension of the National Flood Insurance Program through the end of September was included in a $19 billion disaster aid package passed by the U.S. House of Representatives yesterday, The Advocate (La.) reported. President Donald Trump is expected to sign the bill.

Great-West Lifeco Inc. subsidiary Great-West Life & Annuity Insurance Co. completed the sale of substantially all of its individual life insurance and annuity business to Protective Life Insurance Co. The business sold includes bank- and corporate-owned life insurance, single premium life insurance, individual annuities and closed-block life insurance and annuities.

White Mountains Insurance Group Ltd. acquired a minority stake in Elementum Advisors LLC for undisclosed terms. White Mountains will also inject $50 million across the asset manager's funds.

AmWINS Group Inc. completed the acquisition of wholesaler and managing general agent Atlantic Risk Specialists for undisclosed terms.

France's CNP Assurances SA is acquiring the 49.9% stake held by Bank of Cyprus Holdings PLC in CNP Cyprus Insurance Holdings for 97.5 million, giving CNP Assurances full ownership.

Suncorp Group Ltd. has completed the sale of Resilium Pty. Ltd., its general insurance distribution business in Australia.

Marsh & McLennan Cos. Inc. put the majority of staff at U.K.-based Guy Carpenter and newly acquired JLT Re "under consultation," meaning that they could be laid off as part of headcount reductions following the completion of Marsh's acquisition of Jardine Lloyd Thompson Group PLC, the Insider wrote.

Now featured on S&P Global Market Intelligence

Spate of tornadoes hit homeowners, private auto insurers: There have already been about 1,000 preliminary reports of tornadoes across the U.S. in 2019. The country sees fewer than 1,300 twisters in an average year.

Big tech risks for insurers 'dwarfed' by scale of opportunity: The biggest challenge insurers face from technology is in figuring out how to take advantage of the opportunities it presents while not disrupting existing businesses too much, said KBW's co-head of European research, William Hawkins.

Allstate, AmFam hike personal auto rates in April; Progressive makes cuts: Regulators across six states approved 18 rate-increase requests by Allstate that may lead to an aggregate premium increase of $80.0 million.

In other parts of the world

Asia-Pacific: IAG exits New Zealand life insurance business; Fitch cuts ICICI Bank's ratings

Europe: Fresh UK insider trading probe; Piraeus in 328M deal; France vs Credit Suisse

Middle East & Africa: Absa's Ghanaian unit fined; Kenya moves to curb illicit flows

The day ahead

Early morning futures indicators pointed to a higher opening for the U.S. market.

In Asia, Hang Seng fell 0.49% at 26,761.52, while the Nikkei 225 dropped 0.01% to 20,408.54.

In Europe, around midday, the FTSE 100 lifted 0.12% to 7,193.65, and the Euronext 100 gained 0.09% to 1,027.18.

Click here to read about today's financial markets, setting out the factors driving stocks, bonds and currencies around the world ahead of the New York open.

On the macro front

The motor vehicle sales report, the Redbook Index for retail sales and the factory orders report are due out today.

The Daily Dose has an editorial deadline of 7:30 a.m. ET. Some external links may require a subscription. Links are current as of publication time, and we are not responsible if those links are unavailable later.

urn:contentItem:5SM3-NB11-F0J6-J20F-00000-00June funding cost spike takes $A twist;Financing2018-06-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisMARKET WRAPPg. 31June funding cost spike takes $A twistFinancingVesna Poljak

Funding costs are rising heading into the end of the June quarter, where a two-year high for the bank bill swap rate shows that although the Reserve Bank of Australia is on hold, the cost of finance can still increase materially.

Markets can expect a similar spike in the bank bill swap rate, or BBSW, in the lead-up to September's quarter-end, ANZ senior interest rate strategist Martin Whetton warned on Thursday. The rate will likely fall back in July, but the BBSW - which represents the short-term funding costs of the banks - appears to have moved firmly away from the levels achieved when liquidity was abundant.

More repo, or repurchasing, activity going on in the lead-up to June 30 means that cash is more expensive for market participants who have to reduce their exposures before the calendar year is ruled off. To do this they need physical cash or cash equivalents, largely for technical and regulatory reasons, but the impact of this had a pronounced effect on BBSW at the March quarter-end too.

But this time, rates experts have noticed that Australian dollar financing has become sharply more expensive than its US equivalent. This is evident in the gap between three-month BBSW and LIBOR, the benchmark for US funding, over their respective overnight rates, which is at its widest in seven years.

This can also be observed currently in foreign exchange forwards, repo rates and in the cross-currency basis swap market, which is where investors can swap floating rates between different currencies.

"There's nothing to suggest that it's sinister just yet, we expect these things to be high as we get to quarter-end as the historical pattern shows," said Tamar Hamlyn, portfolio manager at fixed income boutique Ardea. "My feeling would be that it's a bit too early for a pronounced and sustained increase, these are wholesale financial markets. Most corporates don't refinance every day, but a lot of corporate borrowing will be tied to a bank bill swap rate plus a spread.

"If that rate remains high it is going to mean higher financing costs for anybody that's got variable rate financing in Australia, banks have to borrow money at BBSW as well."

The move is not being attributed to the updated composition of BBSW, which changed in May.

"There is a global dimension to this starting with the US," said Nomura rates strategist Andrew Ticehurst, who observes that multinationals outside the US are holding fewer US dollars. This is a consequence of President Donald Trump's move to incentivise US firms to repatriate money sitting idle offshore. The equivalent US bank bill rate moved higher and most reference rates moved in sympathy. It also meant, according to ANZ, that big tech companies would no longer be the marginal buyers of US Treasury bills.

That global dimension is missing in the run-up to June 30, Mr Ticehurst pointed out, where the move in Australia is not being replicated to the same extent in New Zealand, Britain or the US. Some participants speculated that it was because Australian banks were inclined to raise more of their short-term financing in the domestic market instead of in the offshore market, but others believed this to be a strictly an anticipatory effect for now.

"Australia has a large need for $A funding reflective of local funding needs and Australia's current account deficit," wrote Richard Grace, Commonwealth Bank's chief currency strategist, on Thursday. At the same time, Australia's US-dollar funding needs are minimal.

The volume of repo outstanding is at a record high, according to ANZ, including the usage of repo by non-resident investors, which is at 52 per cent of total outstanding repo as of March.

Key pointsAustralian dollar financing has become more expensive than its US equivalent.

Australian corporations are more reliant on local currency financing.
