Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:4BNF-SNX0-00VK-H15R-00000-00Juniper to buy NetScreen in big tech tie-up2004-02-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisAFPJuniper to buy NetScreen in big tech tie-up

SUNNYVALE, United States : Telecom equipment giant Juniper Networks said said it would buy NetScreen Technologies in a four billion dollar deal for the maker of products that make Internet networks more secure.

Juniper, which makes routers that direct Internet traffic across data networks, gains from NetScreen access to hardware and software designed to improve the security and reliability of corporate networks.

Scott Kriens, chairman and chief executive of Silicon Valley-based Juniper, said "Our collective customers have told us security, reliability and performance are mission critical to their network users, and together we will deliver a compelling response to their needs."

Analyst Gabe Lowy with Blaylock and Partners said the deal expands Juniper's product portfolio nicely, but that it comes at a rich price considering NetScreen's expected growth, heightened competition and its focus on the maturing firewall market.

Shares of Juniper Networks dropped 10 percent to 26.48 while NetScreen shares jumped 38 percent to 36.29 in midday trading.

The deal is expected to close in the second quarter and still must be approved by shareholders of both companies. The companies also must get regulatory approvals for the deal.

- AFP

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T6N-D3W1-F15W-H4YJ-00000-00JURRIEN TIMMER, DIRECTOR OF GLOBAL MACRO, FIDELITY INVESTMENT IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG T.V.2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisJURRIEN TIMMER, DIRECTOR OF GLOBAL MACRO, FIDELITY INVESTMENT IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG T.V.

September 5, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

JURRIEN TIMMER, DIRECTOR OF GLOBAL MACRO, FIDELITY INVESTMENT

STEEL: Joining us from Boston is Jurrien Timmmer, Fidelity Investments Director of a Global Macro. Jurrien, good to see you, can that divergence continue?

TIMMER: Yes, you know, it's really an amazing thing that we're seeing, you know. So it's not unusual for the E.M. to lag behind the S&P or even lead it but it tends to always happen when everything is going in the same direction, right. So just one cycle it's consistent with the other, but it's deeper or stronger. But what we're seeing today actually is something that I've never seen before.

So, earnings growth in E.M. is decelerating from, let's say 20 percent six months ago to only eight percent which is still decent but it's a very significant deceleration. And U.S. earnings growth is accelerating from 12 percent to 24 percent. So, having one actually go up and the other go down is very unusual. And when you look at prices, it's the same thing, right. So off the January highs that we said for all markets at the MSCI, E.M. index is down 19 percent, the S&P is up one percent. So we have a 20 percentage point differential but it's happening in completely opposite direction. So that's really a first.

STEEL: And Jurrien, we have a chart that you brought to us that shows just that and I love this. It's hard to get a read on here otherwise. You have earnings growth is the purple line in the U.S. and then everything else is everything else. You got E.M., you got Europe, et cetera. What does that mean? Does that mean they were having like small caps and big tech lead the rally here and can that continue at some point as the rest of the world like catch up or do we drift lower?

TIMMER: So the U.S. cycle is very strong and it certainly got a big shot in the arm from the corporate tax cuts. So, the U.S. economy is basically booming, you know, we saw that PMIs yesterday at new highs since 2004. And the economy, I would say it's overheating but it's certainly growing very strongly that puts the Fed into play. And this is happening at a time when, you know, E.M. and Europe are OK but they're much softer and certainly China is going through a weakening cycle here.

And so when the U.S. is tightening policy monetarily and the rest of the world is still easy, then you get a stronger dollar, you get tightening liquidity conditions. And as you know, E.M. is always at sort of the in the crosshairs of either tightening liquidity or easing liquidity because E.M. tends to borrow in dollars, they tend to borrow a lot. So as the dollar goes off, liquidity conditions tightened.

So, this is a tale of two cycles sort of mind the gap if you will between the two. Eventually, the gap will resolve when the markets starts to see the light at the end of the tunnel in terms of when the Fed is going to be done with its tightening cycle and when the ECB and other central banks get closer and closer to the end of their easing cycle. But we're not really there yet and I don't suspect that we'll be there for the next really 3-6 months at the earliest.

WESTIN: So Jurrien, as you were speaking as we put up a chart that illustrated the fact that now the balance sheets of the central banks has started to come off. And so that start with the tightness, I think global liquidity's tightening up at the same time. That necessarily exacerbates what we're seeing with E.M. because that tends to strengthen the dollar. Is it possible that Fed might actually take this through account and slow down a little bit on what is called normalization?

TIMMER: Not yet, I don't think. So, we at least (ph) in 2015 into early 2016, where we had a similar divergence between the U.S. and E.M. and that was centered around China, of course, China love capital flight, because, again, it was importing this stronger dollar from the U.S. and China's currency of course is linked to the U.S. dollar. And at that point we had the so called Shanghai accord and nobody really knows if it actually ever happened, but in early '16, the Fed started to back off by slowing down its hawkish forward guidance.

And, you know, the irony is is that the Fed basically eased by tightening less quickly than it said it was going to. So it's always a reminder that flow is what drives the market, not the level. It's the rate of change. But at this point we're 2.5 years later further into the cycle. We're closer and closer to late cycle. I don't think the Fed has the luxury of just saying, you know what, we're going to hold off here for six months. I think we're close enough towards late cycle that the Fed doesn't feel it has the luxury that it had 2.5 years ago to just pause. And if it doesn't have that luxury, that means it's going to keep raising rates, maybe another three or four over the next 12 to 18 months. And what the ECB is still kind of not starting its taper, let alone actually shrinking its balance sheet, that create still this policy divergence.

And, you know, to the point about central bank balance sheets, we look at the big for balance sheets, their assets relative to the debt of the countries is peaking at about 36 percent. Three years from now it's likely to be about 31 percent, so we are going slowly towards that more global tightening regime.

STEEL: Right.

TIMMER: And what that does to term premiums and risk premiums everywhere is a big question more often.

STEEL: So Jurrien, quickly, where is the value though in E.M.? What's getting taken out to the wood shed that shouldn't be?

TIMMER: Well, I mean even within China there's a lot of different sectors. You know, India is a great story but it's very expensive, it's actually more expensive than the U.S. Russia's trading at a six P.E. but, you know, it's Russia. So, there are always values but I think it's more on the sector basis.

So if you can buy a solid consumer kind of Staples Company in China, you know there's going to be a market for that, but those stocks even when E.M. had sold off in the past had been relatively expensive. So you have to go into the cyclical side and playoff of, you know, the copper energy and metals materials and then you get into sort of the countries that produce commodities for China.

But China is the key here. It's slowing. The Chinese policymakers are starting to ease fiscally, monetarily. China goes through this two-year cycle and we're kind of getting to the bottom of it. So, at some point we're going to get a policy response out of China that will start lifting the growth rates over there and maybe that's when this pick up between E.M. and the U.S. market starts to close.

WESTIN: Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity Investments will be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So Jurrien, if that plays out that way, I mean deregulations still here. We have the tax cut don't seem to be going away. What differences it make to their ordinary investor whether in fact the Democrats take the house?

TIMMER: Yes. I don't think it makes a big difference. As you said, you know, we have the tax cuts, the deregulation or the lesser enforcement of existing regulations is already happening. It's likely to continue to happen. And trade obviously is likely to continue to be an issue especially into the next presidential election cycle. I do think it's a political issue.

So I don't really see anything really changing from the markets perspective, because those are the things that the markets care about things that affect the economy. And so in that sense, a lot has already been done and if there's a lame duck, you know, situation over the next two years, I don't think it really hurts the market. It's not like there's something that really needs to happen that won't happen in terms of the economy.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: Jurrien, what about trade and specifically Canada when it comes to NAFTA because there are a lot of Republicans as well as Democrats right now who are saying they are not happy with the notion of leaving Canada out and there are arguments -- good arguments that the president can do that by himself?

TIMMER: Yes, you know, I mean it's hard to really know what is real and what isn't anymore. So, if Canada walks away one day, that doesn't mean there won't be a deal a week later. So, I don't know how to handicap that, but I think, you know, the U.S. certainly is playing from a position of strength right now and I think, you know, the White House is taking full advantage of that. But, you know, I don't really know how that's going to play out but my guess is that ultimately there will be bilateral deals, maybe not a NAFTA deal but certainly a country to country deal.

But, you know, that's going to be here six months from now as it is now and I don't think those issues are going to go away very soon, and even if there's a Canada deal, the issues with China will probably linger on for some time because that's much more of a bigger stage in terms of this whole trade chess game if you will. But, you know, ultimately I think what is going to really drive the markets over the next 12-18 months is the Fed and how far do they go and at what point do they declare victory and say, you know what, we've tightened enough. And that's something that nobody knows and ultimately it will be driven by inflation and whether that starts to really accelerate or not.

WESTIN: OK, Jason Draho of UBS Global Wealth Management thank you so much. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity is going to be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So, Jurrien, I'm going to put up chart here actually. It shows the U.S. monthly trade balance over time and this was as of last month of about 57 -- $47 billion is going to be farther to the south and (ph) $50 billion over to the far right. But, does this illustrate something fundamental with the economy? We talked about how it's really going gang busters, the U.S. economy, but aren't we doing that by borrowing money? And as of a practical manner by borrowing money, doesn't that almost inshore trade balance deficit?

TIMMER: Yes. I mean, you know, trade balances are not necessarily bad. I mean, the U.S. is a strong economy that's very much a consumption driven economy. It's about 70 percent of GDP. And so, it kind of makes sense that if goods are produced cheaper elsewhere that we would buy them from there and that would create a trade deficit and then those dollars get recycled and you end up with, you know, China holding treasury bonds as far as their F.X. reserves. And you see historically a very strong correlation with when foreign exchange reserves rise which happens when there's trade, it tends to boost E.M.

So right now, you know, reserves are falling, they're still growing but at a decelerating pace. And that's how I would describe the global economy. You know, the global economy is growing but in the U.S. it's growing and acceleration and in the rest of the world it's growing and decelerating.

So, especially when you have these divergent cycles in place, you're going to see some of these numbers sort of pop out as they have.

STEEL: Yes.

TIMMER: And, again, as I said earlier, ultimately, how this cycle converges again is really the big question, you know, does the U.S. fall and catch up to the rest of the world or does the rest of the world catch up by going up?

(BREAK)

STEEL: Fair point. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity and Bloomberg's Michael McKee thank you very much.

(BREAK)

END

WESTIN: Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity Investments will be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So Jurrien, if that plays out that way, I mean deregulations still here. We have the tax cut don't seem to be going away. What differences it make to their ordinary investor whether in fact the Democrats take the house?

TIMMER: Yes. I don't think it makes a big difference. As you said, you know, we have the tax cuts, the deregulation or the lesser enforcement of existing regulations is already happening. It's likely to continue to happen. And trade obviously is likely to continue to be an issue especially into the next presidential election cycle. I do think it's a political issue.

So I don't really see anything really changing from the markets perspective, because those are the things that the markets care about things that affect the economy. And so in that sense, a lot has already been done and if there's a lame duck, you know, situation over the next two years, I don't think it really hurts the market. It's not like there's something that really needs to happen that won't happen in terms of the economy.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: Jurrien, what about trade and specifically Canada when it comes to NAFTA because there are a lot of Republicans as well as Democrats right now who are saying they are not happy with the notion of leaving Canada out and there are arguments -- good arguments that the president can do that by himself?

TIMMER: Yes, you know, I mean it's hard to really know what is real and what isn't anymore. So, if Canada walks away one day, that doesn't mean there won't be a deal a week later. So, I don't know how to handicap that, but I think, you know, the U.S. certainly is playing from a position of strength right now and I think, you know, the White House is taking full advantage of that. But, you know, I don't really know how that's going to play out but my guess is that ultimately there will be bilateral deals, maybe not a NAFTA deal but certainly a country to country deal.

But, you know, that's going to be here six months from now as it is now and I don't think those issues are going to go away very soon, and even if there's a Canada deal, the issues with China will probably linger on for some time because that's much more of a bigger stage in terms of this whole trade chess game if you will. But, you know, ultimately I think what is going to really drive the markets over the next 12-18 months is the Fed and how far do they go and at what point do they declare victory and say, you know what, we've tightened enough. And that's something that nobody knows and ultimately it will be driven by inflation and whether that starts to really accelerate or not.

WESTIN: OK, Jason Draho of UBS Global Wealth Management thank you so much. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity is going to be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So, Jurrien, I'm going to put up chart here actually. It shows the U.S. monthly trade balance over time and this was as of last month of about 57 -- $47 billion is going to be farther to the south and (ph) $50 billion over to the far right. But, does this illustrate something fundamental with the economy? We talked about how it's really going gang busters, the U.S. economy, but aren't we doing that by borrowing money? And as of a practical manner by borrowing money, doesn't that almost inshore trade balance deficit?

TIMMER: Yes. I mean, you know, trade balances are not necessarily bad. I mean, the U.S. is a strong economy that's very much a consumption driven economy. It's about 70 percent of GDP. And so, it kind of makes sense that if goods are produced cheaper elsewhere that we would buy them from there and that would create a trade deficit and then those dollars get recycled and you end up with, you know, China holding treasury bonds as far as their F.X. reserves. And you see historically a very strong correlation with when foreign exchange reserves rise which happens when there's trade, it tends to boost E.M.

So right now, you know, reserves are falling, they're still growing but at a decelerating pace. And that's how I would describe the global economy. You know, the global economy is growing but in the U.S. it's growing and acceleration and in the rest of the world it's growing and decelerating.

So, especially when you have these divergent cycles in place, you're going to see some of these numbers sort of pop out as they have.

STEEL: Yes.

TIMMER: And, again, as I said earlier, ultimately, how this cycle converges again is really the big question, you know, does the U.S. fall and catch up to the rest of the world or does the rest of the world catch up by going up?

(BREAK)

STEEL: Fair point. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity and Bloomberg's Michael McKee thank you very much.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5T6R-DF51-DY0W-44PV-00000-00Jurrien Timmer is interviewed on BB TV2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisJurrien Timmer is interviewed on BB TVLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ALIX STEEL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining us from Boston is Jurrien Timmmer, Fidelity Investments Director of a Global Macro. Jurrien, good to see you, can that divergence continue?

JURRIEN TIMMER, DIRECTOR OF GLOBAL MACRO, FIDELITY INVESTMENT: Yes, you know, it's really an amazing thing that we're seeing, you know. So it's not unusual for the E.M. to lag behind the S&P or even lead it but it tends to always happen when everything is going in the same direction, right. So just one cycle it's consistent with the other, but it's deeper or stronger. But what we're seeing today actually is something that I've never seen before.

So, earnings growth in E.M. is decelerating from, let's say 20 percent six months ago to only eight percent which is still decent but it's a very significant deceleration. And U.S. earnings growth is accelerating from 12 percent to 24 percent. So, having one actually go up and the other go down is very unusual. And when you look at prices, it's the same thing, right. So off the January highs that we said for all markets at the MSCI, E.M. index is down 19 percent, the S&P is up one percent. So we have a 20 percentage point differential but it's happening in completely opposite direction. So that's really a first.

STEEL: And Jurrien, we have a chart that you brought to us that shows just that and I love this. It's hard to get a read on here otherwise. You have earnings growth is the purple line in the U.S. and then everything else is everything else. You got E.M., you got Europe, et cetera. What does that mean? Does that mean they were having like small caps and big tech lead the rally here and can that continue at some point as the rest of the world like catch up or do we drift lower?

TIMMER: So the U.S. cycle is very strong and it certainly got a big shot in the arm from the corporate tax cuts. So, the U.S. economy is basically booming, you know, we saw that PMIs yesterday at new highs since 2004. And the economy, I would say it's overheating but it's certainly growing very strongly that puts the Fed into play. And this is happening at a time when, you know, E.M. and Europe are OK but they're much softer and certainly China is going through a weakening cycle here.

And so when the U.S. is tightening policy monetarily and the rest of the world is still easy, then you get a stronger dollar, you get tightening liquidity conditions. And as you know, E.M. is always at sort of the in the crosshairs of either tightening liquidity or easing liquidity because E.M. tends to borrow in dollars, they tend to borrow a lot. So as the dollar goes off, liquidity conditions tightened.

So, this is a tale of two cycles sort of mind the gap if you will between the two. Eventually, the gap will resolve when the markets starts to see the light at the end of the tunnel in terms of when the Fed is going to be done with its tightening cycle and when the ECB and other central banks get closer and closer to the end of their easing cycle. But we're not really there yet and I don't suspect that we'll be there for the next really 3-6 months at the earliest.

DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: So Jurrien, as you were speaking as we put up a chart that illustrated the fact that now the balance sheets of the central banks has started to come off. And so that start with the tightness, I think global liquidity's tightening up at the same time. That necessarily exacerbates what we're seeing with E.M. because that tends to strengthen the dollar. Is it possible that Fed might actually take this through account and slow down a little bit on what is called normalization?

TIMMER: Not yet, I don't think. So, we at least (ph) in 2015 into early 2016, where we had a similar divergence between the U.S. and E.M. and that was centered around China, of course, China love capital flight, because, again, it was importing this stronger dollar from the U.S. and China's currency of course is linked to the U.S. dollar. And at that point we had the so called Shanghai accord and nobody really knows if it actually ever happened, but in early '16, the Fed started to back off by slowing down its hawkish forward guidance.

And, you know, the irony is is that the Fed basically eased by tightening less quickly than it said it was going to. So it's always a reminder that flow is what drives the market, not the level. It's the rate of change. But at this point we're 2.5 years later further into the cycle. We're closer and closer to late cycle. I don't think the Fed has the luxury of just saying, you know what, we're going to hold off here for six months. I think we're close enough towards late cycle that the Fed doesn't feel it has the luxury that it had 2.5 years ago to just pause. And if it doesn't have that luxury, that means it's going to keep raising rates, maybe another three or four over the next 12 to 18 months. And what the ECB is still kind of not starting its taper, let alone actually shrinking its balance sheet, that create still this policy divergence.

And, you know, to the point about central bank balance sheets, we look at the big for balance sheets, their assets relative to the debt of the countries is peaking at about 36 percent. Three years from now it's likely to be about 31 percent, so we are going slowly towards that more global tightening regime.

STEEL: Right.

TIMMER: And what that does to term premiums and risk premiums everywhere is a big question more often.

STEEL: So Jurrien, quickly, where is the value though in E.M.? What's getting taken out to the wood shed that shouldn't be?

TIMMER: Well, I mean even within China there's a lot of different sectors. You know, India is a great story but it's very expensive, it's actually more expensive than the U.S. Russia's trading at a six P.E. but, you know, it's Russia. So, there are always values but I think it's more on the sector basis.

So if you can buy a solid consumer kind of Staples Company in China, you know there's going to be a market for that, but those stocks even when E.M. had sold off in the past had been relatively expensive. So you have to go into the cyclical side and playoff of, you know, the copper energy and metals materials and then you get into sort of the countries that produce commodities for China.

But China is the key here. It's slowing. The Chinese policymakers are starting to ease fiscally, monetarily. China goes through this two-year cycle and we're kind of getting to the bottom of it. So, at some point we're going to get a policy response out of China that will start lifting the growth rates over there and maybe that's when this pick up between E.M. and the U.S. market starts to close.

WESTIN: Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity Investments will be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So Jurrien, if that plays out that way, I mean deregulations still here. We have the tax cut don't seem to be going away. What differences it make to their ordinary investor whether in fact the Democrats take the house?

TIMMER: Yes. I don't think it makes a big difference. As you said, you know, we have the tax cuts, the deregulation or the lesser enforcement of existing regulations is already happening. It's likely to continue to happen. And trade obviously is likely to continue to be an issue especially into the next presidential election cycle. I do think it's a political issue.

So I don't really see anything really changing from the markets perspective, because those are the things that the markets care about things that affect the economy. And so in that sense, a lot has already been done and if there's a lame duck, you know, situation over the next two years, I don't think it really hurts the market. It's not like there's something that really needs to happen that won't happen in terms of the economy.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: Jurrien, what about trade and specifically Canada when it comes to NAFTA because there are a lot of Republicans as well as Democrats right now who are saying they are not happy with the notion of leaving Canada out and there are arguments -- good arguments that the president can do that by himself?

TIMMER: Yes, you know, I mean it's hard to really know what is real and what isn't anymore. So, if Canada walks away one day, that doesn't mean there won't be a deal a week later. So, I don't know how to handicap that, but I think, you know, the U.S. certainly is playing from a position of strength right now and I think, you know, the White House is taking full advantage of that. But, you know, I don't really know how that's going to play out but my guess is that ultimately there will be bilateral deals, maybe not a NAFTA deal but certainly a country to country deal.

But, you know, that's going to be here six months from now as it is now and I don't think those issues are going to go away very soon, and even if there's a Canada deal, the issues with China will probably linger on for some time because that's much more of a bigger stage in terms of this whole trade chess game if you will. But, you know, ultimately I think what is going to really drive the markets over the next 12-18 months is the Fed and how far do they go and at what point do they declare victory and say, you know what, we've tightened enough. And that's something that nobody knows and ultimately it will be driven by inflation and whether that starts to really accelerate or not.

WESTIN: OK, Jason Draho of UBS Global Wealth Management thank you so much. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity is going to be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So, Jurrien, I'm going to put up chart here actually. It shows the U.S. monthly trade balance over time and this was as of last month of about 57 -- $47 billion is going to be farther to the south and (ph) $50 billion over to the far right. But, does this illustrate something fundamental with the economy? We talked about how it's really going gang busters, the U.S. economy, but aren't we doing that by borrowing money? And as of a practical manner by borrowing money, doesn't that almost inshore trade balance deficit?

TIMMER: Yes. I mean, you know, trade balances are not necessarily bad. I mean, the U.S. is a strong economy that's very much a consumption driven economy. It's about 70 percent of GDP. And so, it kind of makes sense that if goods are produced cheaper elsewhere that we would buy them from there and that would create a trade deficit and then those dollars get recycled and you end up with, you know, China holding treasury bonds as far as their F.X. reserves. And you see historically a very strong correlation with when foreign exchange reserves rise which happens when there's trade, it tends to boost E.M.

So right now, you know, reserves are falling, they're still growing but at a decelerating pace. And that's how I would describe the global economy. You know, the global economy is growing but in the U.S. it's growing and acceleration and in the rest of the world it's growing and decelerating.

So, especially when you have these divergent cycles in place, you're going to see some of these numbers sort of pop out as they have.

STEEL: Yes.

TIMMER: And, again, as I said earlier, ultimately, how this cycle converges again is really the big question, you know, does the U.S. fall and catch up to the rest of the world or does the rest of the world catch up by going up?

(BREAK)

STEEL: Fair point. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity and Bloomberg's Michael McKee thank you very much.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

So if you can buy a solid consumer kind of Staples Company in China, you know there's going to be a market for that, but those stocks even when E.M. had sold off in the past had been relatively expensive. So you have to go into the cyclical side and playoff of, you know, the copper energy and metals materials and then you get into sort of the countries that produce commodities for China.

But China is the key here. It's slowing. The Chinese policymakers are starting to ease fiscally, monetarily. China goes through this two-year cycle and we're kind of getting to the bottom of it. So, at some point we're going to get a policy response out of China that will start lifting the growth rates over there and maybe that's when this pick up between E.M. and the U.S. market starts to close.

WESTIN: Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity Investments will be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So Jurrien, if that plays out that way, I mean deregulations still here. We have the tax cut don't seem to be going away. What differences it make to their ordinary investor whether in fact the Democrats take the house?

TIMMER: Yes. I don't think it makes a big difference. As you said, you know, we have the tax cuts, the deregulation or the lesser enforcement of existing regulations is already happening. It's likely to continue to happen. And trade obviously is likely to continue to be an issue especially into the next presidential election cycle. I do think it's a political issue.

So I don't really see anything really changing from the markets perspective, because those are the things that the markets care about things that affect the economy. And so in that sense, a lot has already been done and if there's a lame duck, you know, situation over the next two years, I don't think it really hurts the market. It's not like there's something that really needs to happen that won't happen in terms of the economy.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: Jurrien, what about trade and specifically Canada when it comes to NAFTA because there are a lot of Republicans as well as Democrats right now who are saying they are not happy with the notion of leaving Canada out and there are arguments -- good arguments that the president can do that by himself?

TIMMER: Yes, you know, I mean it's hard to really know what is real and what isn't anymore. So, if Canada walks away one day, that doesn't mean there won't be a deal a week later. So, I don't know how to handicap that, but I think, you know, the U.S. certainly is playing from a position of strength right now and I think, you know, the White House is taking full advantage of that. But, you know, I don't really know how that's going to play out but my guess is that ultimately there will be bilateral deals, maybe not a NAFTA deal but certainly a country to country deal.

But, you know, that's going to be here six months from now as it is now and I don't think those issues are going to go away very soon, and even if there's a Canada deal, the issues with China will probably linger on for some time because that's much more of a bigger stage in terms of this whole trade chess game if you will. But, you know, ultimately I think what is going to really drive the markets over the next 12-18 months is the Fed and how far do they go and at what point do they declare victory and say, you know what, we've tightened enough. And that's something that nobody knows and ultimately it will be driven by inflation and whether that starts to really accelerate or not.

WESTIN: OK, Jason Draho of UBS Global Wealth Management thank you so much. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity is going to be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So, Jurrien, I'm going to put up chart here actually. It shows the U.S. monthly trade balance over time and this was as of last month of about 57 -- $47 billion is going to be farther to the south and (ph) $50 billion over to the far right. But, does this illustrate something fundamental with the economy? We talked about how it's really going gang busters, the U.S. economy, but aren't we doing that by borrowing money? And as of a practical manner by borrowing money, doesn't that almost inshore trade balance deficit?

TIMMER: Yes. I mean, you know, trade balances are not necessarily bad. I mean, the U.S. is a strong economy that's very much a consumption driven economy. It's about 70 percent of GDP. And so, it kind of makes sense that if goods are produced cheaper elsewhere that we would buy them from there and that would create a trade deficit and then those dollars get recycled and you end up with, you know, China holding treasury bonds as far as their F.X. reserves. And you see historically a very strong correlation with when foreign exchange reserves rise which happens when there's trade, it tends to boost E.M.

So right now, you know, reserves are falling, they're still growing but at a decelerating pace. And that's how I would describe the global economy. You know, the global economy is growing but in the U.S. it's growing and acceleration and in the rest of the world it's growing and decelerating.

So, especially when you have these divergent cycles in place, you're going to see some of these numbers sort of pop out as they have.

STEEL: Yes.

TIMMER: And, again, as I said earlier, ultimately, how this cycle converges again is really the big question, you know, does the U.S. fall and catch up to the rest of the world or does the rest of the world catch up by going up?

(BREAK)

STEEL: Fair point. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity and Bloomberg's Michael McKee thank you very much.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5T6R-DF51-DY0W-44PW-00000-00Jurrien Timmer is interviewed on BB TV2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisJurrien Timmer is interviewed on BB TVWalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ALIX STEEL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining us from Boston is Jurrien Timmmer, Fidelity Investments Director of a Global Macro. Jurrien, good to see you, can that divergence continue?

JURRIEN TIMMER, DIRECTOR OF GLOBAL MACRO, FIDELITY INVESTMENT: Yes, you know, it's really an amazing thing that we're seeing, you know. So it's not unusual for the E.M. to lag behind the S&P or even lead it but it tends to always happen when everything is going in the same direction, right. So just one cycle it's consistent with the other, but it's deeper or stronger. But what we're seeing today actually is something that I've never seen before.

So, earnings growth in E.M. is decelerating from, let's say 20 percent six months ago to only eight percent which is still decent but it's a very significant deceleration. And U.S. earnings growth is accelerating from 12 percent to 24 percent. So, having one actually go up and the other go down is very unusual. And when you look at prices, it's the same thing, right. So off the January highs that we said for all markets at the MSCI, E.M. index is down 19 percent, the S&P is up one percent. So we have a 20 percentage point differential but it's happening in completely opposite direction. So that's really a first.

STEEL: And Jurrien, we have a chart that you brought to us that shows just that and I love this. It's hard to get a read on here otherwise. You have earnings growth is the purple line in the U.S. and then everything else is everything else. You got E.M., you got Europe, et cetera. What does that mean? Does that mean they were having like small caps and big tech lead the rally here and can that continue at some point as the rest of the world like catch up or do we drift lower?

TIMMER: So the U.S. cycle is very strong and it certainly got a big shot in the arm from the corporate tax cuts. So, the U.S. economy is basically booming, you know, we saw that PMIs yesterday at new highs since 2004. And the economy, I would say it's overheating but it's certainly growing very strongly that puts the Fed into play. And this is happening at a time when, you know, E.M. and Europe are OK but they're much softer and certainly China is going through a weakening cycle here.

And so when the U.S. is tightening policy monetarily and the rest of the world is still easy, then you get a stronger dollar, you get tightening liquidity conditions. And as you know, E.M. is always at sort of the in the crosshairs of either tightening liquidity or easing liquidity because E.M. tends to borrow in dollars, they tend to borrow a lot. So as the dollar goes off, liquidity conditions tightened.

So, this is a tale of two cycles sort of mind the gap if you will between the two. Eventually, the gap will resolve when the markets starts to see the light at the end of the tunnel in terms of when the Fed is going to be done with its tightening cycle and when the ECB and other central banks get closer and closer to the end of their easing cycle. But we're not really there yet and I don't suspect that we'll be there for the next really 3-6 months at the earliest.

DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: So Jurrien, as you were speaking as we put up a chart that illustrated the fact that now the balance sheets of the central banks has started to come off. And so that start with the tightness, I think global liquidity's tightening up at the same time. That necessarily exacerbates what we're seeing with E.M. because that tends to strengthen the dollar. Is it possible that Fed might actually take this through account and slow down a little bit on what is called normalization?

TIMMER: Not yet, I don't think. So, we at least (ph) in 2015 into early 2016, where we had a similar divergence between the U.S. and E.M. and that was centered around China, of course, China love capital flight, because, again, it was importing this stronger dollar from the U.S. and China's currency of course is linked to the U.S. dollar. And at that point we had the so called Shanghai accord and nobody really knows if it actually ever happened, but in early '16, the Fed started to back off by slowing down its hawkish forward guidance.

And, you know, the irony is is that the Fed basically eased by tightening less quickly than it said it was going to. So it's always a reminder that flow is what drives the market, not the level. It's the rate of change. But at this point we're 2.5 years later further into the cycle. We're closer and closer to late cycle. I don't think the Fed has the luxury of just saying, you know what, we're going to hold off here for six months. I think we're close enough towards late cycle that the Fed doesn't feel it has the luxury that it had 2.5 years ago to just pause. And if it doesn't have that luxury, that means it's going to keep raising rates, maybe another three or four over the next 12 to 18 months. And what the ECB is still kind of not starting its taper, let alone actually shrinking its balance sheet, that create still this policy divergence.

And, you know, to the point about central bank balance sheets, we look at the big for balance sheets, their assets relative to the debt of the countries is peaking at about 36 percent. Three years from now it's likely to be about 31 percent, so we are going slowly towards that more global tightening regime.

STEEL: Right.

TIMMER: And what that does to term premiums and risk premiums everywhere is a big question more often.

STEEL: So Jurrien, quickly, where is the value though in E.M.? What's getting taken out to the wood shed that shouldn't be?

TIMMER: Well, I mean even within China there's a lot of different sectors. You know, India is a great story but it's very expensive, it's actually more expensive than the U.S.Russia's trading at a six P.E. but, you know, it's Russia. So, there are always values but I think it's more on the sector basis.

So if you can buy a solid consumer kind of Staples Company in China, you know there's going to be a market for that, but those stocks even when E.M. had sold off in the past had been relatively expensive. So you have to go into the cyclical side and playoff of, you know, the copper energy and metals materials and then you get into sort of the countries that produce commodities for China.

But China is the key here. It's slowing. The Chinese policymakers are starting to ease fiscally, monetarily. China goes through this two-year cycle and we're kind of getting to the bottom of it. So, at some point we're going to get a policy response out of China that will start lifting the growth rates over there and maybe that's when this pick up between E.M. and the U.S. market starts to close.

WESTIN: Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity Investments will be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So Jurrien, if that plays out that way, I mean deregulations still here. We have the tax cut don't seem to be going away. What differences it make to their ordinary investor whether in fact the Democrats take the house?

TIMMER: Yes. I don't think it makes a big difference. As you said, you know, we have the tax cuts, the deregulation or the lesser enforcement of existing regulations is already happening. It's likely to continue to happen. And trade obviously is likely to continue to be an issue especially into the next presidential election cycle. I do think it's a political issue.

So I don't really see anything really changing from the markets perspective, because those are the things that the markets care about things that affect the economy. And so in that sense, a lot has already been done and if there's a lame duck, you know, situation over the next two years, I don't think it really hurts the market. It's not like there's something that really needs to happen that won't happen in terms of the economy.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: Jurrien, what about trade and specifically Canada when it comes to NAFTA because there are a lot of Republicans as well as Democrats right now who are saying they are not happy with the notion of leaving Canada out and there are arguments -- good arguments that the president can do that by himself?

TIMMER: Yes, you know, I mean it's hard to really know what is real and what isn't anymore. So, if Canada walks away one day, that doesn't mean there won't be a deal a week later. So, I don't know how to handicap that, but I think, you know, the U.S. certainly is playing from a position of strength right now and I think, you know, the White House is taking full advantage of that. But, you know, I don't really know how that's going to play out but my guess is that ultimately there will be bilateral deals, maybe not a NAFTA deal but certainly a country to country deal.

But, you know, that's going to be here six months from now as it is now and I don't think those issues are going to go away very soon, and even if there's a Canada deal, the issues with China will probably linger on for some time because that's much more of a bigger stage in terms of this whole trade chess game if you will. But, you know, ultimately I think what is going to really drive the markets over the next 12-18 months is the Fed and how far do they go and at what point do they declare victory and say, you know what, we've tightened enough. And that's something that nobody knows and ultimately it will be driven by inflation and whether that starts to really accelerate or not.

WESTIN: OK, Jason Draho of UBS Global Wealth Management thank you so much. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity is going to be staying with us.

(BREAK)

WESTIN: So, Jurrien, I'm going to put up chart here actually. It shows the U.S. monthly trade balance over time and this was as of last month of about 57 -- $47 billion is going to be farther to the south and (ph) $50 billion over to the far right. But, does this illustrate something fundamental with the economy? We talked about how it's really going gang busters, the U.S. economy, but aren't we doing that by borrowing money? And as of a practical manner by borrowing money, doesn't that almost inshore trade balance deficit?

TIMMER: Yes. I mean, you know, trade balances are not necessarily bad. I mean, the U.S. is a strong economy that's very much a consumption driven economy. It's about 70 percent of GDP. And so, it kind of makes sense that if goods are produced cheaper elsewhere that we would buy them from there and that would create a trade deficit and then those dollars get recycled and you end up with, you know, China holding treasury bonds as far as their F.X. reserves. And you see historically a very strong correlation with when foreign exchange reserves rise which happens when there's trade, it tends to boost E.M.

So right now, you know, reserves are falling, they're still growing but at a decelerating pace. And that's how I would describe the global economy. You know, the global economy is growing but in the U.S. it's growing and acceleration and in the rest of the world it's growing and decelerating.

So, especially when you have these divergent cycles in place, you're going to see some of these numbers sort of pop out as they have.

STEEL: Yes.

TIMMER: And, again, as I said earlier, ultimately, how this cycle converges again is really the big question, you know, does the U.S. fall and catch up to the rest of the world or does the rest of the world catch up by going up?

(BREAK)

STEEL: Fair point. Jurrien Timmer of Fidelity and Bloomberg's Michael McKee thank you very much.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XR1-W6F1-DYTY-C2TJ-00000-00Just another day of world domination;Mr Bezos, your order has been dispatched2018-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisMAGAZINE;NEWSPg. 12,13,14,15,16,17Just another day of world dominationMr Bezos, your order has been dispatched

Amazon is under fire for avoiding taxes, exploiting workers and killing offthe high street. As its owner becomes the richest man on the planet, John Arlidge asks whether the price of convenience is too high Most people who get offthe train in Cambridge head straight to the River Cam for a punt and a stroll past the colleges and laboratories where DNA, embryonic stem cells and much else besides were discovered. Few notice the building opposite the station. With its dull beige walls and green windows, it's no King's College Chapel, but this is where the hi-tech innovations that are changing our lives in once-unimaginable ways are being dreamt up.

In the secret labs on the top floor, with windows frosted to protect from prying eyes, Alexa, Amazon's voice-controlled electronic "assistant", learns how to respond to our questions and commands. Alexa is the device that has kick-started the latest arms race in tech: voice-controlled and -operated smart devices.

Look higher still and you will soon see drones flying over the roof of the Amazon Cambridge Development Centre, to give the building its proper name. These aircraft, which will deliver a six-pack of beer direct to your garden in half an hour or less when the barbecue is running dry, are being designed and tested here by British scientists.

"We're right out at the edge of what you can do with technology," David Hardcastle, the centre's director, says, although the test drone he has just plonked on his desk makes his point rather better. So what's next, I ask. He just smiles and fiddles with his cufflinks, which will probably soon be Alexa-enabled.

Second-guessing Amazon is a mug's www.game.No one will spill the magic beans. But there is one thing that we can predict. Amazon, already nicknamed "the everything store", is fast becoming the "everything, everywhere, every time" store. It's growing so fast that it's now the world's third-largest tech company by revenue, on course to generate sales of $200bn this year. That's $547m a day. Analysts expect sales to reach $350bn by the end of 2020 and to surpass the $500bn mark by 2023.

Its shares are soaring at such a clip - up more than 50% this year - that it is expected to pip Apple to become the world's first trillion - million million - dollar listed company. Last week it became only the second company, after Apple, to pass the $900bn market-value milestone.

That made the firm's founder, JeffBezos, 54, the wealthiest man in modern history, worth $150bn, according to Bloomberg. That's enough to cover Britain's budget deficit. More than twice.

As it grows online - and makes the odd foray into the physical world, notably its recent £11bn acquisition of the US and UK supermarket chain Whole Foods - it will have an even bigger effect on the way we behave, on our towns and cities, and our jobs than it has already wrought - for good or bad.

Make that BAD!, as far as Donald Trump is concerned. The world's most powerful critic is waging a Twitter war on Amazon, accusing it of avoiding tax, bankrupting high-street retailers and destroying the fabric of towns and cities. "Amazon is doing great damage to tax-paying retailers. Towns, cities and states are being hurt - many jobs being lost!" he says.

It's not hard to see why Trump, and many on this side of the Atlantic, are furious, especially those who work at struggling bricks-and-mortar retailers. Amazon's global digital shop is fast replacing the high street. It's already on our desktops, iPads and mobile phones, and now, thanks to Alexa, in our homes and even our cars, with manufacturers such as Toyota, BMW and JaguarLand Rover installing "her".

Whatever device we use to shop, there's always more to buy. The firm's recent $1bn acquisition of PillPack, an online pharmacy start-up, takes it into healthcare, threatening Boots in the same way that the first product it sold, books, threatened Waterstones. Banks are in the firing line. Amazon wants to offer current accounts. Ocado is under attack, too, after Amazon's decision to partner with Morrisons to offer Amazon Fresh home food delivery.

And shopping is just the start. Amazon is fast becoming a media giant. Amazon Music is already the world's third-largest digital music service by subscribers, behind Spotify and Apple Music. Television shows like Jeremy Clarkson's The Grand Tour have helped to make Amazon's Prime Video the fastest-growing new entertainment service in Britain last year, overtaking Netflix. Subscribers increased 41% to 4.3m households last year, says Barb, the ratings body. Subscriber figures will rise sharply once it starts screening sports. It has bought the rights to the US Open tennis and will livestream 20 Premier League football matches per season from 2019-2020.

What makes a simple shop so irresistible that even those of us who agree with Trump's criticism still use it to buy most of the stuffwe need, read novels on Kindle, watch TV and now wake up with Alexa? Can it continue to escape the scrutiny and public disgust hammering the other tech giants, notably Facebook? Amazon has grown so big, so fast and been largely ignored by regulators because it is different. Not necessarily better than its west coast US rivals, but different. To find out how, you have to go to 2117-2127, 7th Avenue, Seattle.

The first distinction is as clear as the summer sky around the company's head office the day I arrive. Amazon is not, like its biggest tech competitors, in Silicon Valley. Nor does it look like anything in "the Valley". Its 45,000 Seattle-based staffdo not work in a perfectly formed bubble, unencumbered by the awkward intrusion of reality. Amazon's $4bn mothership is spread over 10m sq ft in more than 40 buildings downtown. That helps Amazon never to lose sight of its customers. "It inspires us to invent for them every day," says Sam Kennedy, from Nashville, the first Amazonian I meet.

Customers never lose sight of Amazon, either. The entrance to Amageddon is marked by glass domes. The Spheres - to Amazon, or "JeffBezos's balls" to everyone else - are 90ft high and 130ft wide, and filled with 40,000 plants. Modelled on the greenhouses at Kew Gardens, they are a place for employees "to feel differently, to think differently", Amazon says. (Not for too long, though. Bezos monitors the time his employees spend there). Their main role is to demonstrate transparency. They practically scream: "Look inside. We've nothing to hide. We're not Facebook!" All the tech behemoths like to think they are take-no-prisoners innovators, but Bezos raises the bar. He reminds his human drones to push harder every day by calling the main 37-storey tower of his HQ Day 1 because "every day is day one at Amazon". If they forget the firm's scrappy start-up culture, what will follow is "painful decline. Followed by death." The company's values, pasted on walls everywhere, increase the pressure. "Have Backbone! Bias for action!", the signs scream.

It's tough all right, but also a refreshing change from the platitudes beloved of most west coast US firms - "Don't be evil" (Google) or "Connect the world" (Facebook). But do the people who work at a firm that is almost 25 years old and set to become the most valuable in the history of modern capitalism really buy such motivational woo-woo? They do. Really. "I love waking up every day worried about my customers," Prentis Wilson, who heads up Amazon's business services, tells me - with one of his trademark awkward corporate smiles that seems to mimic Amazon's logo. Stephenie Landry, who pioneered the Prime Now service that offers delivery in cities in a couple of hours, may dress like a hippie but she describes gleefully how "ruthless prototypation" and long, long days enabled her to set up Prime Now in New York in just 111 days. That's not moving fast and breaking things. That's being on tech crack.

Perhaps that's why Amazonians don't mind doing without the perks enjoyed by staffat Google and Facebook. Another of Amazon's core values posted on every noticeboard is "Frugality!" There's no free food and stafftravel economy class - all except Bezos, who has a private jet and a spaceship, New Shepard, in case he can't find anywhere on earth he wants to fly to.

Bezos may be tough, but he likes to be challenged himself. Amazon HQ staffare encouraged to write their own messages on the walls alongside company values. Not all criticism is wiped clean by the thought police. On my visit, Amazonians ridiculed Bezos's decision to sell limited-edition 355ml bottles of Amazon-branded Coca-Cola at $10, five times the price of a regular bottle. Over a large poster advertising the drink, one wrote "$10 fan coke is wrong". Another drew a face crying with laughter.

But perhaps the biggest difference between Amazon and its Silicon Valley peers is its attitude to making money. Most big tech outfits like to charge a lot for the gadgets they create and rack up vast profits. Amazon, by contrast, does not seek to make much money at all from its devices. "We break even," says David Limp, head of devices, whose haircut is so neat and whose clothes are so crisp he looks rather like a device himself. He's not kidding. A Kindle ereader starts at £60, compared to £400 for an Apple iPad Mini, and an Alexa "Echo" Dot can be yours for £50, six times less than Apple's rival HomePod.

Amazon can do this because it subsidises devices and its retail arm with the vast profit its makes from Amazon Web Services (AWS), its cloud-computing arm. AWS sells pay-as-you-go computing power, data storage and content delivery to everyone from the smallest start-up to the CIA, raking in $20bn a year. It's the little-known power behind Bezos's empire and even if you want to escape it, you can't. Like Netflix? You're swelling Amazon's coffers. The streaming giant depends on AWS.

Amazon does, of course, work very hard to hook us on using its devices once we've bought them - and then charge us even more for premium subscriptions, such as Prime, which offers almost unlimited fast delivery and TV. It does this because the more we shop, watch and download, the more data it gathers that it can use to offer us new products. Even then, it uses low prices to lure us, which means lower margins. It made just $3bn profit on $178bn revenues last year. Huge investment in research and development also eats into profits. Amazon sunk $23bn into R&D last year, a record for any company.

Amazon has enjoyed a stellar run by any measure, but nothing lasts for ever. The company is coming under scrutiny as concerns about privacy and the monopoly power the big tech firms enjoy increase. Trump, riled as much by criticism in The Washington Post, which Bezos owns, as by Amazon's growth, accuses the firm of everything from tax avoidance to bankrupting the US post office by not paying its fair share of delivery costs.

Rival retailers are lobbying Trump to break up Amazon. Bill Simon, former boss of Walmart, the largest big box retailer in the world, argues Amazon abuses its dominant position in ecommerce to undercut and drive competitors out of business. He has a point. A cursory web search reveals story after story of vendors who complain that Amazon has forced them to sell their goods on its platform on lousy terms. Some smaller companies even claim Amazon has tried to bankrupt them by copying their hit products and then selling them at a lower price, sometimes below cost. One small San Francisco-based company, Rain Design, sold a $43 aluminium laptop stand that garnered almost universally positive reviews, making it the bestseller in its category. Then last year Amazon came out with an eerily similar stand for $20. Sales of the Rain Design original slipped. "We don't feel good about it," says Harvey Tai, Rain's general manager, with crashing understatement. Amazon has not commented on claims it "copied" the stand.

Although the Rain Design stand is still selling decently on Amazon, it's cases like this that prompt critics to say Bezos is mounting a cut-price land grab to secure market domination. Then, once he has achieved it, he will push up prices and we will have no choice but to pay. From his office in New York, Scott Galloway, a professor of marketing at New York University and an outspoken critic of big tech, tells me: "Dictators always start benign, but power corrupts." Many consumers are already complaining that despite signing up to "all you can eat" packages, such as Prime, they are charged extra to watch movies and listen to music.

Margrethe Vestager, the fearsome EU competition chief, is also on Amazon's case. She's fed up with being given the runaround by companies, including Amazon, that - legally - try to avoid tax by shifting profits from high-tax countries, such as Britain, to low-tax ones such as Luxembourg and Ireland, or simply structure their businesses so that they make little profit to avoid tax. Amazon paid £7.4m in tax in Britain in 2016, despite generating more than £7bn in revenues here. Amazon points out it has restructured its tax arrangements, so that it now pays more tax. But it still has a big cost advantage over its bricks-and-mortar rivals. Paula Nickolds, the new boss of John Lewis, points out that, unlike her company, Amazon does not have to pay rent or business rates here on branded stores because it does not have any.

It's certainly tempting to paint Bezos as a 21st-century version of the robber barons of the oil or railways age. Amazon will control nearly half of the ecommerce market in the US by the end of this year, a new report from eMarketer says. It is set to become No 1 in US clothing and footwear later this year, with 38% of those markets. In western Europe it accounts for 22% of the ecommerce market and controls more than 80% of the ebook market.

It's also hard to disagree that Amazon and other online retailers are hollowing out town and city centres and malls. One lunchtime in Seattle I walk the few blocks from Amazon's HQ to Macy's department store on Pine Street. It's so quiet inside that shopping is like intruding on private grief. Or it would be, if there were anything to buy: the shelves are a jumble of outdated styles. Last year was a record year for store closures in America, with nearly 8,000 shutting and only 3,000 opening. Here, House of Fraser, Maplin, Toys R Us and Comet have all fallen victim to the rise of online retail. Some 5,855 shops closed across Britain last year, according to the accountancy firm PWC, more than in any year since 2010. The number of new shops opening also continued to fall, with a net loss of 1,700.

But Amazon thinks it has a trump card. By delivering ever lower prices, it argues it is the opposite of a greedy monopolist. "I wake up every day thinking customers are better offthan they were 10 years ago," says Greg Greeley, former head of Amazon Prime, when I pose the question everyone always wants to ask Amazon: do you wake up worrying about putting yet another bricks-and-mortar store out of business? Amazon executives add that while it may dominate certain markets, notably online books, when you take into account the total retail market, it is only a small fraction - 2% in the UK and 4% in the US. As for pressuring smaller rivals, they point out that 2m small-and medium-sized businesses around the world rely on Amazon to fulfil their orders. Last year, for the first time, independent companies' orders fulfilled by Amazon exceeded sales by Amazon itself.

But what about all the jobs that are disappearing from the high street? Surely Russ Grandinetti, a man-mountain of a hometown boy who runs Amazon's international business, feels a little guilty about what his firm has wrought? "The building we're in now didn't exist three years ago. I see a building going up over there that we are constructing. What we've done for this town, for the country, for the world is productive," he insists as he gestures out of his many office windows. "We create lots of jobs not only in the company - 100,000 in the US last year alone, 5,000 in Britain - but also in the suppliers we serve." He adds that the firm is set to open a new $5bn campus in North America, creating up to 50,000 jobs.

Grandinetti does concede that there are losers in the ecommerce revolution and helping them is "important". But "where that nets out I don't really think is ours to tally. Companies have often invented technologies that have then required us to figure out how to reinvest the productivity improvements in new jobs and new ways. That's an important societal thing to do, an important governmental thing to do. I don't think it's our job to do anything but try to be really good at what we do." Shareholders will cheer his relentless focus on the bottom line. Critics will respond that he is turning a blind eye to the disruption Amazon causes.

If Amazon has an Achilles heel, it is in its comically named fulfilment centres - its giant warehouses. They are anything but fulfilling for the people who work there. Scarcely a month goes by without a newspaper sending an undercover reporter to record how staffwork crippling shifts. To meet performance targets, insiders say pickers must collect as many as 1,000 items and walk up to 15 miles in a single shift. Timers count the seconds needed to retrieve each item, with penalties for those who are too sluggish. Pressure to hit targets means there is scant time for lavatory breaks or lunch, workers claim. James Bloodworth, who got a job at Amazon's warehouse in Rugeley in Staffordshire, revealed in a recent book that workers who have a day offsick - even with a doctor's note - get a disciplinary point against their name. Amazon has since ended this practice. Wages, however, remain low. Amazon disclosed in April its workers' median annual salary is $28,446, which means a typical employee would have to work more than 5m years to rack up Bezos's current net worth. Thousands of workers at Amazon's warehouses in Germany went on strike earlier this month to demand better working conditions, joining colleagues in Spain and Poland. Germany's Verdi services union accused the company of getting rich by "saving money on the health of its workers".

Grandinetti concedes that "specific anecdotes" are "not as we would like", but points out that Amazon staffget company pensions, health insurance and shares.

Fulfilment centres "are and have been good places to work. Absolutely."

Can anything stop the world's biggest data-driven instant-gratification company? On my final afternoon in Seattle, I ask Gur Kimchi, the Israel-born scientist, who oversees Amazon's tech centre in Cambridge and has already test-flown the first local delivery - a bag of popcorn. We debate the rights and wrongs of big tech but he's heard it all before and it has turned his hair salt'n'pepper. He wants to move on. "Let me leave you with a parting thought," he says. "If you think drones are exciting, think about the other 50 projects - bonkers, crazy projects - we can't tell you about." Alexa-enabled spectacles? Not weird enough.

An Alexa implant so she can tell us what to do, not the other way around? Like Hardcastle, Kimchi is not giving anything away, but his parting message is clear: Trump or no Trump, the online mega mall that sells soap powder and makes soap operas, online marketplace, music box, online advertiser, cloud-computer services provider, bank, audible-books player, supermarket chain, food-delivery service, ereader manufacturer, always-on home help, CIA's little helper, online car dashboard, drone squadron, pharmacy chain, creator of warehouses where Dickens meets robots and much, much else - is only just getting started

Early learning Amazon's first name was Cadabra but became Amazon after a lawyer misheard it as "Cadaver". Bezos settled on Amazon because a giant river reflected the scale of his ambitions

Electronics Since Amazon's voice-operated "butler" - activated by saying its name, Alexa - launched three years ago, the number of American newborns named Alexa has fallen by one-third

Last week, Amazon became the second company ever to pass the $900bn market value milestone. Only Apple is worth more

Innovations Amazon spent $23bn on research and development last year, more than any other company in the world

Grocery & Gourmet Food To speed up decision-making, Amazon has a two-pizza rule: no meeting should involve more people than can be fed by two pizzas

Gift Cards Last year, Amazon retained $3bn from unredeemed gift cards

pets' corner Dogs are welcome at Amazon's new $4bn campus in Seattleprime movers Left, from top: JeffBezos, Amazon's founder; David Hardcastle, head of the Development Centre in Cambridgethe world is not enough Left, from top: Bezos's spaceship, New Shepard, blasts offin Texas for a test flight; an old-school convenience store for staffin Amazon's Day 1 building in SeattleBelow: a living wall inside one of the glass Spheres at theentrance to the Seattle complexamazonian tribe Above: gadget guru David Limp. Right: head of international business, Russ Grandinetti; Stephenie Landry, pioneer of Prime Nowshop horror Left: the gloomy picture on British high streets as bricks-andmortar retailers struggle to cope with the Amazon effect

urn:contentItem:60MP-CNM1-F07F-844P-00000-00Just how big is Facebook’s misinformation problem?2020-08-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:50ZLexisNexisNEWSJust how big is Facebook’s misinformation problem?Alexandra S. Levine
